| ''[[12 Years a Slave (film)|12 Years a Slave]]'' || 2013 || The film is based on [[Twelve Years a Slave|the true story]] of [[Solomon Northup]], a free black man who was kidnapped in [[Washington, D.C.]] in 1841 and sold into slavery.<ref name="samuels" /> |- | ''[[500 Years Later]]'' || 2005 || Documentary covering the onset of [[slavery]], its subsequent [[colonialism]], and how Africans are still struggling for basic freedom. |- | ''[[Abe Lincoln in Illinois (film)|Abe Lincoln in Illinois]]'' || 1940 || The early life of [[Abraham Lincoln]] and his rise to becoming president. |- | ''[[Abraham Lincoln (1930 film)|Abraham Lincoln]]'' || 1930 || A biopic of Abraham Lincoln and his role as president during the [[American Civil War]]. |- | ''[[Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter]]'' || 2012 || Based on the novel of the same name, it portrays Abraham Lincoln as becoming a vampire hunter mostly in secret. |- | ''[[The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn (1939 film)|The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn]]'' || 1939 || [[Mark Twain|Mark Twain's]] [[Huckleberry Finn (character)|title character]] befriends and takes a raft down the Mississippi River with [[Jim (Huckleberry Finn)|Jim]], an escaped slave hoping to win his freedom. Later films of the book were also made in [[The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn (1960 film)|1960]], [[Hopelessly Lost|1973]] (Soviet Union film ''[[Hopelessly Lost]]''), [[Huckleberry Finn (1974 film)|1974]], [[Huckleberry Finn (1975 film)|1975]], [[Huckleberry no Bouken|1976]] (Japanese anime series), and [[The Adventures of Huck Finn (1993 film)|1993]]. |- | ''[[Aferim!]]'' || 2015 || Tragic adventure comedy telling the story of a bounty hunter in pursuit of a Romani (Gypsy) slave in 1835 Wallachia. |- | ''[[Alex Haley's Queen]]'' || 1993 || Based on the life of Queen Jackson Haley, [[Alex Haley]]'s paternal grandmother. |- | ''[[Amazing Grace (2006 film)|Amazing Grace]]'' || 2006 || Amazing Grace is a biographical movie about the Abolitionist [[William Wilberforce]]'s campaign against the slave trade in the British Empire, and features the role of [[John Newton]], the writer of the hymn ''[[Amazing Grace]]'', in Wilberforce's campaign. |- | ''[[Amistad (film)|Amistad]]'' || 1997 || In 1839, a [[slave revolt]] takes place on the Spanish ship [[La Amistad]] which is [[Slavery in the Spanish New World colonies|heading to Cuba]]. Two white survivors are ordered to navigate the ship back to Africa, but navigate the ship to the United States instead. The slaves then have to fight for their freedom in court, where they are [[United States v. The Amistad|eventually defended]] by ex-U.S. president [[John Quincy Adams]].<ref name="root" /> |- | ''[[Ashanti (1979 film)|Ashanti]]'' || 1979 || Using modern day slave-trading and set in Africa, a white doctor goes on a journey to find his wife who was mistaken for a native woman and kidnapped by slave traders while swimming. Getting no help from the police or the local authorities, the doctor gets a lead and tracks his missing wife across the country with a couple of allies. |- | ''[[Band of Angels]]'' || 1957 || Love story set around the US Civil War in which a plantation owner with a past raises a black slave as his son and buys a posh mixed race slave girl.<ref name="angels" /> |- | ''[[Battlefield Earth (film)|Battlefield Earth]]'' || 2000 || In this film, humanity has been enslaved by an race known as the Psychlos.<ref name="Battlefield">{{cite news|last=Serafino|first=Jason|title=5 Movies Influenced By Scientology|work=[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]|date=June 4, 2013|url=http://www.complex.com/pop-culture/2013/06/movies-influenced-by-scientology/battlefield-earth|accessdate =2016-01-13}}</ref> |- | ''[[Belle (2013 film)|Belle]]'' || 2013 || Story of Dido Elizabeth Belle, a mixed-race child of a British Royal Navy Officer, and her involvement in the legal case of the Zong massacre. |- | ''[[Beloved (1998 film)|Beloved]]'' || 1998 || A former slave experiences flashbacks to her past as a slave.<ref name="root" /> |- | ''[[Ben-Hur (1959 film)|Ben-Hur]]'' || [[Ben-Hur (1925 film)|1925]], [[Ben-Hur (1959 film)|1959]] & [[Ben-Hur (2016 film)|2016]] || A first century Jewish prince is forced to become a [[galley slave]]. |- | ''[[The Birth of a Nation (2016 film)|The Birth of a Nation]]'' || 2016 || [[Nat Turner]], a former slave in America, leads a liberation movement in 1831 to free [[African-Americans]] in Virginia that results in a violent retaliation from whites. |- | ''[[List of The Book of Negroes episodes|''The Book of Negroes'']] || 2015 || A Canadian television series based on [[The Book of Negroes (novel)|the book]] of the same name. |- | ''[[Boy Slaves]]'' || 1939 || An exposé of child labor. Children entrapped in [[peonage]] strike for better food, try to alert the government, but fail in these attempts. |- | ''[[Brother Future]]'' || 1991 || Brother Future is a science fiction movie. A street kid from Detroit, Michigan, is hit by a car, and when he awakens, he finds himself a slave in South Carolina in 1822. The boy then has to help his fellow slaves so that he can return to his own time. |- | ''[[Burn!]]'' || 1969 || An [[agent provocateur]] is sent to the fictional island of Queimada, a Portuguese colony in the Caribbean to replace the Portuguese administration by a formally sovereign state controlled by white [[latifundia|latifundists]] friendly to Great Britain. To realize this project, the agent persuades the black slaves to fight for their liberation from slavery. |- | ''[[Caribbean Gold]]'' || 1952 || |- | ''[[Captain Blood (1935 film)|Captain Blood]]'' || 1935 || An enslaved Irish doctor becomes a pirate. |- | ''[[Cloud Atlas (film)|Cloud Atlas]]'' |2012 |Plotlines involving escapes from historical and futuristic forms of slavery |- | ''[[C.S.A.: The Confederate States of America]]'' || 2004 || A faux British documentary of today reviewing American history, operating under the counter-historical premise that the [[Confederate States of America]] won the [[American Civil War]], annexed all of the United States in the process, and thereby preserved and expanded slavery throughout the nation. |- | ''[[Django Unchained]]'' || 2012 || In the [[American South]] in 1858, a slave is purchased by a [[Germany|German]] [[dentist]] turned [[bounty hunter]], and then agrees to help him track down a small group of dangerous outlaws in exchange for his freedom and the rescuing of his wife from a cruel plantation owner. |- | ''[[Drum (1976 film)|Drum]]'' || 1976 || The film, a sequel to ''[[Mandingo (film)|Mandingo]]'', features a black slave who falls in love with a plantation owner's daughter. When the owner threatens castration, the slave plans a revolt.<ref name="root" /> |- | ''[[El Cimarron (film)|El Cimarron]]'' || 2007 || Based on the life of [[Marcos Xiorro]] who conspired and planned a [[slave revolt]] in [[Puerto Rico]] in 1821. |- | ''[[Enslavement: The True Story of Fanny Kemble]]'' || 2000 || The film depicts the story of British actress and abolitionist [[Fanny Kemble]], who becomes horrified by [[Treatment of slaves in the United States|the treatment of her husband's enslaved people]]. Fanny later publishes her journals and their [[Slave narrative|first-hand accounts]] of slavery, helping influence the British government's decision to withhold support of the [[Confederate States of America|Confederacy]] during the [[American Civil War]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=20000423&slug=4016942 |title='Enslavement' takes some liberties with abolitionist Fanny Kemble's tale |work=[[The Seattle Times]] |publisher=[[The Seattle Times Company]] |first=Misha|last=Berson |date=April 23, 2000 |accessdate=October 7, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.philly.com/2000-04-21/news/25588871_1_pierce-butler-story-of-fanny-kemble-masterpiece-theatre |title=Hysterical drama of historical figure |work=[[Los Angeles Daily News]] |publisher=[[MediaNews Group]] |first=David |last=Kronke |date=April 21, 2000 |accessdate=October 7, 2013}}</ref> |- | ''[[Fortunes of Captain Blood]]'' || 1950 || |- | ''[[The Foxes of Harrow]]'' || 1947 || Covering approximately the years 1827–1837, an illegitimate son of an Irish aristocratic family comes to America. He is a gambler and scoundrel who acquires a large plantation with many slaves, and builds an empire in antebellum [[New Orleans]]. The movie was the first based upon a book written by an African-American writer.<ref name="root" /> |- | ''[[Free State of Jones (film)|Free State of Jones]]'' || 2016 || Disenchanted [[Confederate States Army|confederate]] soldiers rally with runaway slaves to establish an abolitionist colony in Mississippi, led by [[Newton Knight]], who fathers a child with a black woman. That story is framed by the one of his great-grandsons, who is prosecuted in 1948 for attempting to marry a white woman while possibly being of mixed descent. |- | ''[[Frederick Douglass and the White Negro]]'' || 2008 || A documentary telling the story of ex-slave, [[Abolitionism in the United States|abolitionist]], writer and politician [[Frederick Douglass]] and his escape to Ireland from America in the 1840s. |- | ''[[Freedom (2014 film)|Freedom]]'' || 2014 || In the United States in the 1850s, a black man attempts to free his family from a tobacco plantation.<ref name="samuels" /> |- | ''[[Ganga Zumba (film)|Ganga Zumba]]'' || 1963 || Not released until 1972 because of a military coup in Brazil, the film highlights [[Ganga Zumba]], a 17th-century slave revolutionary. |- | ''[[Gladiator (2000 film)|Gladiator]]'' || 2000 || A Roman general in the 2nd century A.D. is turned into a slave who must fight for his life, and his country, as a [[gladiator]]. |- | ''[[Glory (1989 film)|Glory]]'' || 1989 || During the [[American Civil War]], an escaped slave joins an all-black fighting unit of the [[Union Army]].<ref name="root" /> |- | ''[[Goodbye Uncle Tom]]'' || 1971 || ''Addio Zio Tom'' is a pseudo-documentary in which the filmmakers go back in time and visit antebellum America, using period documents to examine, in graphic detail, the racist ideology and degrading conditions faced by Africans under slavery.<ref name="root" /> |- | ''[[Gone with the Wind (film)|Gone with the Wind]]'' || 1939 || The film features a slave nursemaid as a prominent supporting character. Actress [[Hattie McDaniel]] made history by becoming the first [[African American]] woman to win an [[Academy Award]] for her performance ([[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]]).<ref name="root" /> |- | ''[[A House Divided: Denmark Vesey's Rebellion]]'' ||1982|| A 1982 television film about Denmark Vesey, a literate skilled carpenter and former slave who planned a slave rebellion in 1822 in Charleston, South Carolina. |- | ''[[I Am Slave]]'' || 2010 || A U.K. television story of one woman's fight for freedom from modern-day slavery, based on the experience of [[Mende Nazer]], a British author, human rights activist, and a former [[Slavery in Sudan|slave in Sudan]]. |- | ''[[Ill Gotten Gains]]'' || 1997 || Independent film about the [[Atlantic slave trade]] |- | ''[[Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom]]'' || 1984 || In the film, [[child slavery|enslaved children]] are forced to mine for Sankara stones. |- | ''[[Jefferson in Paris]]'' || 1995 || The film shows the relationship between [[Thomas Jefferson]], who was one of the Founding Fathers of the United States and a slave owner, and [[Sally Hemings]], a biracial slave.<ref name="root" /> |- | ''[[Joseph (film)|Joseph]]'' || 1995 || The biblical story of [[Joseph (son of Jacob)|Joseph]] and his brothers. Joseph is an Egyptian slave who earns a reputation as an interpreter of dreams. |- | ''[[Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat (film)|Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat]] || 1999 || [[Joseph (son of Jacob)|Joseph's]] biblical story portrayed in a musical by [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]], starred [[Donny Osmond]] as Joseph. |- | ''[[Joseph: King of Dreams]]'' || 2000 || The Biblical story of Joseph portrayed in an animated musical. |- | ''{{sortname|The|Journey of August King}}'' || 1995|| A widowed farmer reluctantly provides safe passage to a run-away slave as he returns home from an annual trip to purchase provisions and supplies, starring [[Jason Patric]] as August King and [[Thandie Newton]] as Annalees. |- | ''{{sortname|The|Keeping Room}}'' || 2014 || The film takes place during the [[American Civil War]]. Three women in the South have to protect their home against soldiers of the [[Union Army]].<ref name="samuels" /> |- | ''[[The Last Supper (1976 film)|The Last Supper]]'' || 1976 || A [[plantation]] owner during [[Spanish colonization of the Americas|Spanish colonial]] times recreates the last supper using slaves, in order to teach them about [[Christianity]]. |- | ''{{sortname|The|Legend of Nigger Charley}}'' || 1972 || The [[blaxploitation]] film takes place in America in the [[Antebellum era|Antebellum South]]. It follows three slaves seeking their freedom. |- | ''[[The Legend of Tarzan (film)|The Legend of Tarzan]]''|| 2016 || [[George Washington Williams]] convinces [[Tarzan]] (John Clayton III, the Earl of Greystoke) to travel back to Africa to investigate claims of an ongoing slave trade. |- | ''[[Lincoln (2012 film)|Lincoln]]'' || 2012 || Near the end of the [[American Civil War]], President [[Abraham Lincoln]] pushes to abolish slavery in the U.S. by urging Congress to pass the [[Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution]].<ref name="root" /> |- | ''[[The Littlest Rebel]]'' || 1935 || |- | ''[[Manderlay]]'' || 2005 || Set in the early 1930s, the film tells the story of Grace, an idealist who attempts to oust the owners of a plantation in Alabama and free the slaves living there. |- | ''[[Mandingo (film)|Mandingo]]'' || 1975 || A slave owner insists that his son, who is sleeping with the slaves, marry a white woman and father him a son. He marries, and trains a Mandingo slave to be a bare-knuckle fighter. |- | ''[[Motherland (2010 film)|Motherland]]'' || 2010 || Documentary sequel to ''[[500 Years Later]]'', the film gives an overview of the history of the African continent and its people from Ancient Egypt to the present. |- |''[[Nat Turner: A Troublesome Property]]'' || 2003 || Documentary film about Nat Turner |- | ''[[North and South (TV miniseries)|North and South]]'' || 1985–1994 || A three-part TV miniseries outlining the period leading to and during the American civil war, and the post-war [[Reconstruction era of the United States|Reconstruction]]. |- | ''{{sortname|The|North Star|dab=film}}'' || 2013 || The film is based on "the true story of Big Ben Jones, a slave who escaped from a Southern plantation in 1848 and is helped by local [[Quakers]]".<ref name="samuels" /> |- | ''[[Passage du milieu]]'' || 1999 || [[Docudrama]] about a [[Atlantic slave trade|trans-Atlantic]] [[slave ship]] voyage of black slaves from the West Coast of Africa to the Caribbean, a part of the [[triangular slave trade]] route called the [[Middle Passage]]. |- | ''[[Paradesi (2013 film)|Paradesi]]'' || 2013 || A Tamil language movie that is based on true events that took place in a tea plantation during the 1930s. |- | ''[[Prince Among Slaves (film)|Prince Among Slaves]]'' || 2006 || A [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] historical documentary about the life of [[Abdulrahman Ibrahim Ibn Sori]], a prince from West Africa who was made a slave in the United States and freed 40 years later on orders of the American president, [[John Quincy Adams]]. |- | ''[[The Prince of Egypt]]'' || 1998 || Former Prince [[Moses]] frees the Hebrew slaves from the [[Pharaoh]] of [[Egypt]]. |- | ''[[Quilombo (film)|Quilombo]]'' || 1984 || Account of [[Quilombo dos Palmares]], a 17th-century Brazilian community of escaped slaves. Features its one-time leader, [[Zumbi]]. |- | ''[[Raiders of the Seven Seas]]'' || 1953 || |- |''[[The Retrieval]]'' |2013 |During the Civil War, a young free boy is sent north by his bounty hunter gang to retrieve a wanted fugitive slave. |- | ''[[Return of the Jedi]]'' || 1983 || (Arguably the captivity of Princess Leia in Jabba the Hutt's court makes the institution a side-theme.) |- | ''[[Roots (1977 miniseries)|Roots]]'' || 1977 || An acclaimed eight-episode TV mini-series based on [[Alex Haley]]'s biography about his family moving from slavery to liberation.<ref name="root" /> |- | ''[[Roots (2016 miniseries)|Roots]]'' || 2016 || A four-episode remake of the 1977 miniseries. |- | ''[[Roots: The Gift]] || 1988 || A film portraying events occurring between the second and third episodes of the first miniseries. |- | ''[[Sankofa (film)|Sankofa]]'' || 1993 || In the supernatural film, a black American model travels to [[Ghana]] and is transported back in time by a local mystic. The model finds herself a slave in the past.<ref name="root" /> |- | ''[[Santa Fe Trail (film)|Santa Fe Trail]]'' || 1940 || Western centered around abolitionist [[John Brown (abolitionist)|John Brown]], his attacks on slavery as a prelude to the Civil War, and the attempt to find his hideout and stop his violent campaign. |- | ''[[Savannah (film)|Savannah]]'' || 2013 || Loosely based on the book ''Ducks, Dogs and Friends'', the film is about a white hunter who befriends a freed slave.<ref name="samuels" /> |- | ''[[Seven Angry Men]]'' || 1955 || Follows John Brown's campaign to end slavery and his raid on [[John Brown's raid on Harpers Ferry|Harper's Ferry]]. |- | ''[[The Slave Hunters]]'' || 2010 || Slave hunter goes after an escaped General-turned-slave in this South Korean 24-episode television series. |- | ''[[Slaves (film)|Slaves]]'' || 1969 || Follows the life of two slaves in the American South of the 1850s. |- | ''[[Solomon Northup's Odyssey]]'' || 1984 || The film is based on the true story of [[Solomon Northup]], a free black man who was kidnapped in [[Washington, DC]] in 1841 and sold into slavery.<ref name="corry" /> |- | ''[[Spartacus (film)|Spartacus]] || [[Spartacus (film)|1960]] & [[Spartacus (miniseries)|2004]] || In [[Spartacus]], a film that stays close to the historical record,<ref>Davis, ''Slaves on Screen: Film and Historical Vision'' (2002) ch 3</ref> a [[Thracian]] enslaved as a gladiator by the [[Roman Republic]] leads a [[Third Servile War|slave revolt]] that engulfs much of the Italian peninsula. |- | ''[[Tamango]] || 1958 || A slave ship crosses the Atlantic, and the slaves rebel. A film by [[Hollywood Blacklist|Hollywood blacklisted]] director [[John Berry (film director)|John Berry]] starring [[Dorothy Dandridge]] and [[Curd Jürgens]]. |- | ''[[The Ten Commandments (1956 film)|The Ten Commandments]]'' || [[The Ten Commandments (1923 film)|1923]] & [[The Ten Commandments (1956 film)|1956]] || [[Bible|Biblical]] story of the life of [[Moses]], an adopted [[Ancient Egypt|Egyptian]] prince who becomes the deliverer of his real brethren, the enslaved [[Israelites|Hebrews]]. |- | ''[[Tula: The Revolt]]'' || 2013 || In 1795 on [[Curaçao]], then a Dutch colony, a slave uprising takes place.<ref name="samuels" /> |- | ''[[The Viking (1928 film)|The Viking]] || 1928 || Lord Alwin is captured in a viking raid and taken to Norway as a slave.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0019532/|title=The Viking (1928)|website=IMDB}}</ref> |- | ''[[Unchained Memories]]'' || 2003 || An [[HBO]] documentary featuring the stories of former slaves interviewed during the 1930s as part of the [[Federal Writers' Project]]. It compiles slave narratives which are narrated by actors emulating the original conversation with the interviewer. |- | ''[[Film adaptations of Uncle Tom's Cabin|Uncle Tom's Cabin]]'' || 1903||Many film adaptations of [[Harriet Beecher Stowe|Harriet Beecher Stowe's]] novel have been made, nine from the silent era (including those of [[Uncle Tom's Cabin (1910 Thanhouser film)|1910]], [[Uncle Tom's Cabin (1918 film)|1918]], and [[Uncle Tom's Cabin (1927 film)|1927]]), and a [[Uncle Tom's Cabin (1965 film)|German version]] in 1965. |- | ''[[A Woman Called Moses]]'' || 1978 || A film about the life and career of the [[African American]] abolitionist and slave escape leader, [[Harriet Tubman]]. |- | ''[[A Woman Captured]]'' || 2017 || A documentary about a woman who is kept as domestic slave in Europe. |- | ''[[Zama (2017 film)|Zama]]'' || 2017 || The film is set in the late 18th century in a remote South American colony under the [[Spanish Empire]], and portrays the period's "naturalness of slavery".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lavoz.com.ar/numero-cero/el-arte-de-la-espera-esta-semana-se-estrena-zama-de-lucrecia-martel|title=El arte de la espera: esta semana se estrena "Zama", de Lucrecia Martel|date=September 24, 2017|language=Spanish|work=[[La Voz del Interior]]|accessdate=November 19, 2017|last=Koza|first=Roger}}</ref> |}
==See also== * ''[[Underground (TV series)|Underground]]'' (2016 TV series)
==References== {{Reflist|refs= <ref name="angels">{{cite news | title=Top Grosses of 1957 | work=Variety | date= January 8, 1958 }}</ref> <ref name="corry">{{cite news | last=Corry | first=John | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/02/13/arts/tv-review-solomon-northrup-s-odssey-story-of-a-slave.html | title=TV Review; 'Solomon Northrup's Odyssey,' Story of a Slave | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=February 13, 1985 }}</ref> <!-- <ref name="patterson">{{cite news | last=Patterson | first=John | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/film/2013/jan/14/django-unchained-exploitation-slavery | title=Django Unchained: the inglorious history of slavery in the movies | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=January 11, 2013 }}</ref>--> <ref name="root">{{cite news | author=Staff | url=http://www.theroot.com/multimedia/12-films-dared-tackle-slavery | title=12 Films That Dared to Tackle Slavery | work=[[The Root (magazine)|The Root]] | year=2012 | accessdate=July 17, 2013 }}</ref> <ref name="samuels">{{cite news | last=Samuel | first=Allison | url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2013/03/15/how-2013-became-the-year-of-the-slavery-film.html | title=How 2013 Became the Year of the Slavery Film | work=[[The Daily Beast]] | date=March 15, 2013 | accessdate=July 17, 2013 }}</ref> }} <note name = "while ... black"> OK, i am disqualifyying myself from doing more about this than drawing attn to it and offering a possible draft for the change. I won't complain if someone thinks i'm a "white phony liberal", but i note my objection to the language i found in one of the entries, along the lines of " marrying a white woman while possibly black". IMO, the phrase "driving [or whatever] while black" is a well established term regarding oppression, and adapting it in the context of describing the film in question is too ambiguous between mockery of the rerm, and an unfamiliar extension of its use in labelling oppression, to be acceptable in an article. Discuss, please, and reword unless i'm mistaken.</ref> {{Filmsbygenre}} {{Slave narrative|state=expanded}} {{Film genres}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.2)
revision.text:
[[File:Bergamo Donizetti.JPG|thumb|Monument to Donizetti, Bergamo]]
The '''Monument to Donizetti''' by [[Francesco Jerace]] is located in a public garden in Piazza Cavour, adjacent to the [[Teatro Donizetti]] in [[Bergamo]].
==Description== The monument was inaugurated in 1897, at the centenary of his birth and in his birthplace, and commemorates the opera composer [[Gaetano Donizetti]]. Jerace was elected via a competition to complete the monument. The statuary group is atop a plain plinth engraved only with the composers name. The monument is surrounded by a Basin. Atop, Donizetti sits, realistically depicted, and bound to present world, in the corner of a curved bench. A short distance away stands the lyrical muse, [[Melpomene]], strumming her lyre. The artist, with eyes closed, listens to his inspiration. The statue mixes both realism and the allegory to classical mythology; also expressing the sense that the artists communicates with a superior realm.<ref>[http://www.scultura-italiana.com/Biografie/Jerace.htm Scultura Italiana] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160602230118/http://www.scultura-italiana.com/Biografie/Jerace.htm |date=2016-06-02 }}, biography.</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=-OMNAAAAYAAJ The Italy of the Italians], by Helen Zimmern, pp. 130–131.</ref> Donizetti's funereal monument in Bergamo, se up in 1856 features a mournful lyrical muse.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Coord|45.69545|9.67171|format=dms|type:landmark_region:IT|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Donizetti Bergamo}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Bergamo]] [[Category:1897 sculptures]] [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1897]] [[Category:Monuments to composers]] [[Category:Statues of musicians]] [[Category:Musical instruments in art]]

{{Infobox ancient site |name = Naveta of Es Tudons<!-- required --> |native_name = Naveta d'Es Tudons |alternate_name = Naveta des Tudons |image =Tudons01.jpg |alt = Naveta of Es Tudons |caption = Façade and side wall of the Naveta d'Es Tudons |map = |map_caption = |map_type = Spain Menorca |map_alt = |coordinates = {{coord|40.003128|3.891558|region:ES|format=dms|display=inline,title}} |map_size = |location = [[Menorca]], [[Balearic Islands]], Spain |region = |type = Burial site |part_of = |length = {{convert|13.60|m}}<ref name=Lagarda/> |width = {{convert|6.40|m}}<ref name=Lagarda/> |area = |height = {{convert|4.50|m}}<ref name=Lagarda/> |builder = |material = limestone |built = 2000-1000 BC<ref name=chap>{{harvnb|Chapman|Grant|1997|pp=71}}</ref> |abandoned = 750 BC |epochs = |cultures = pre-[[Talaiotic culture|Talaiotic age]] |dependency_of = |occupants = |event = |excavations = 1959 |archaeologists = |condition = restored |ownership = |management = |public_access = yes |website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> |notes = }}
The '''Naveta d'Es Tudons''', or '''Naveta of Es Tudons''' (in Menorquí, ''naveta'', or ''naueta'', a diminutive form of ''nau'', means ''nave'',<ref>The monument is sometimes also called ''Nau d'Es Tudons''</ref> and ''Es Tudons'', lit. ''the woodpigeons'', is the name of the place),<ref name=Grinsell>{{harvnb|Grinsell|1975|p=194}}</ref> is the most remarkable [[megalithic]] [[chamber tomb]] in the [[Balearic Islands|Balearic island]] of [[Menorca]], Spain.
It is located in the Western part of the island, on the [[Ciutadella de Menorca]]-[[Port Mahon|Mahón]] road, approximately 3 miles out from Ciutadella, and 200 m south of the road. It stands on slightly rising ground in a sloping valley.<ref>{{harvnb|James|1957|p=67}} [https://archive.org/stream/prehistoricrelig00jame#page/n71/mode/2up]</ref> Currently the Naveta d'Es Tudons is open to the public for visits (except for its interior as a measure of protection). It is one of the main tourist attractions of Menorca.
== History== In Menorca and Majorca there are several dozen habitational and funerary [[naveta]] complexes, some of which similarly comprise two storeys.<ref name=Grinsell/><ref name="GeorgGerster" /><ref name=fdz/> Navetas (''navetes'' in Menorquí) are chronologically pre-Talaiotic (i.e. prior to the [[Talaiotic culture|Talaiotic age]]) constructions.<ref name=fdz>{{harvnb|Fernández Miranda|1997|pp=60–61}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spanisharts.com/arquitectura/imagenes/prehistoria/i_navetas.html|title=Navetas, Menorca, Baleares Islands |work=The History Of The Spanish Architecture}}</ref> Navetas were described in the early 19th century but not excavated until the 20th, notably during the 1960s and 1970s.<ref name="GeorgGerster">{{harvnb|Gerster|2007|p=250 (Es Tudons in Menorca, Spain)}}</ref> Navetas were first given their name by the rather imaginative Dr Juan Ramis (1818) from their resemblance to upturned boats.<ref>{{harvnb|Grinsell|1975|p=193}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Hoskin|Morales Núñez|1991|p=25}}</ref>
The Naveta d'Es Tudons is the largest and best preserved funerary naveta in Menorca. The Naveta d'Es Tudons served as collective [[ossuary]] between 1200 and 750 BC.<ref>{{harvnb|Chapman|Grant|1997|pp=69–71}}</ref> The lower chamber was for stashing the disarticulated bones of the dead after the flesh had been removed<ref name="PhilLee">Phil Lee, ''The Rough Guide to Menorca'', Rough Guides, 2001, 288 p. 187.</ref> while the upper chamber was probably used for the drying of recently placed corpses.<ref>{{harvnb|Blake |Knapp|2005| p=170}}</ref> Radiocarbon dating of the bones found in the different funerary navetas in Menorca indicate a usage period between about 1130-820 BC,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Micó |first=Rafael|title=Radiocarbon dating and balearic prehistory: reviewing the periodization of the prehistoric sequence|journal=Radiocarbon |year=2006|volume=48|issue=3|pages=421–434 |url=https://journals.uair.arizona.edu/index.php/radiocarbon/article/view/2886/2649|accessdate=8 May 2012|issn=0033-8222}}</ref> but the navetas like the Naveta d'Es Tudons are probably older. Pre-Talaiotic constructions are dated using an uncalibrated radiocarbon chronology from 1640 to 1400 BC.<ref name=fdz/> The navetas used for communal burial rituals are dated to the late second millennium and early first millennium BC.<ref name=Lagarda>{{cite web|last=Lagarda i Mata|first=Ferran|title=Es Tudons|url=http://www.menorcaweb.net/arqueologia/menorca/arqme64.htm|work=Menorcaweb.net|accessdate=8 May 2012}}</ref><ref name="chap" />
Although listed in the [[Bien de Interés Cultural|Spanish heritage register]] on 3 June 1931 ([http://toolserver.org/%7Eplatonides/wlm/ids.php?bic=RI-51-0003442&userlang=en RI-51-0003442]), the naveta d'Es Tudons was excavated and restored by archaeologist [[Lluís Pericot García]] in 1959-1960. It was found to contain the remains of at least 100 skeletons (one with trepanned skull). Various recovered objects like [[bronze]] bracelets or bone and ceramic buttons <ref name=Grinsell/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.menorcaweb.com/reports/archaeological-sites/naveta-des-tudons/|work=MenorcaWeb.com |title=Naveta des Tudons}}</ref> are today on display in the [[Museu de Menorca]] in Mahón. Restoration works were carried out and the two or three missing courses at the top were put back in place.<ref name=Grinsell/> For protection, it was surrounded at a distance by a recently restored modern dry stone field wall.<ref>Dominique Auzias, Jean-Paul Labourdette, ''Baléares, Ibiza — Minorque — Majorque'', Le Petit Fûté, 2012, 336 p., p. 281 : "Inutile de vous extasier sur le mur de pierre sèche qui entoure la Naveta, il est de construction récente" ("There is no need for one to enthuse about the dry stone wall surrounding the Naveta, its construction is recent.")</ref>
== Architecture == [[File:Plan and Section of Nau d'Es Tudons 1912.png|thumb|left|Plan and section of the unrestored naveta (1912): ''(a)'' low door, ''(b)'' narrow slab-roofed passage, ''(c)'' long rectangular chamber.<ref>{{harvnb|Peet|1912|p=73}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Cartailhac|1892}}</ref>]]
The shape of the Naveta d'Es Tudons is that of a boat upside down, with the stern as its trapezoidal façade and the bow as its rounded apse. Its groundplan is an elongated semicircle. Externally, the edifice is 14.5 m long by 6.5 m wide and 4.55 m high but it would originally have been 6 m high.<ref name=Grinsell/> It is orientated SWS/ENE, the entrance being at the SWS, in the centre of the slightly slanted (or battered) façade.
The front, side walls and apse of the edifice consist of successive horizontal corbelled courses of huge rectangular or square [[limestone]] blocks dressed with a hammer<ref>{{harvnb|Guillemard|1907|pp=465–467}}</ref> and fitted together without mortar, with an all-round foundation course of blocks of even greater size laid on edge.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artehistoria.jcyl.es/artesp/obras/19331.htm|title= Naveta dels Tudons (Ciutadella, Menorca)]|work=artehistoria|quote=''Toda la construcción se ejecutó mediante sillares de buen tamaño dispuestos en hiladas regulares, excepto el zócalo hecho a base de bloques de mayor tamaño que sirven de cimentación.''}}</ref>
The narrow, low entrance doorway (0.57 m x 0.75 m) is rebated to receive a closing slab. The once sealed-off entrance leads by a short, flag-roofed passage to an antechamber 1.3 m long and then another short passage to the main or lower chamber (7.45 m x 2.45 m), the ceiling of which is made of giant horizontal slabs inserted into the side walls, with an average span of 1.5 m ''c.'' 2.25 m above the floor. Above this is an upper chamber which is accessible from the upper part of the antechamber. It is slightly shorter (7.10 m) and narrower (1.90 m) than the lower chamber, with a similar although much lower (0.85 m) ceiling of horizontal slabs.<ref name=Grinsell/> These have holes in them, presumably for ventilation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stonefoundation.org/gallery/sp02.html|title= Tektonika, a photo gallery - an exhibit of photographs of the stonework of the Balearic Islands & the Catalan mainland|work=Stonefoundation.org}}</ref>
{{clear left}} [[File:Naveta des tudons.jpg|250px|right|thumb|The edifice at dawn, behind its modern wall]]
== Folklore == According to Phil Lee, the author of ''The Rough Guide to Menorca'', folkloric memories of the navetas' original purpose may have survived into modern times, for the Menorcans were loath to go near these odd-looking and solitary monuments until well into the 19th century.<ref name="PhilLee" />
A modern tragic lore tells that two giants were competing for the love of a girl. They agreed that one would build a naveta and the other would dig a water well and the first to finish would marry the girl. As the giant who was building the naveta was about to lay the last stone, the other struck water. Mad with jealousy, the first giant threw the last stone (the one that is missing from the top of the façade) into the well, killing the other giant. Then, feeling remorse, he killed himself. It is said that the girl died a spinster and was buried in the naveta.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} {{clr}}

{{Infobox book | name = No Turn Unstoned: The Worst Ever Theatrical Reviews | title_orig = | translator = | image = | caption = | author = [[Diana Rigg]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = | language = | series = | subject = | genre = | publisher = Elm Tree Books | pub_date = 1982 | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = 192 pp ''(first edition)'' | isbn = 0-241-10855-1 | dewey= 792.9/5 19 | congress= PN1707 .N59 1982 | oclc= 10021707 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} {{Infobox book | name = No Turn Unstoned: The Worst Ever Theatrical Reviews | title_orig = | translator = | image = | caption = | author = [[Diana Rigg]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United Kingdom | language = | series = | subject = | genre = | publisher = [[Arrow Books]] | pub_date = 1983 | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = 291 pp | isbn = 0-09-932270-6 | dewey= 792.9/5 | congress= | oclc= 12469412 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''No Turn Unstoned''''' is a collection of "the worst theatrical reviews in history" compiled by the actress [[Dame (title)|Dame]] [[Diana Rigg]]. The first edition, published by [[Elm Tree Books]] in 1982, did not sell well, but over the years it attained a near-[[cult]] status and a [[paperback]] edition was released in 1991.
Rigg wrote to her many friends and acquaintances in the theatre and film industries and asked them to share their worst-ever reviews. She also researched theatre criticism and surviving comments from as far back as [[Ancient Greece]]. During the early 1990s, Dame Diana toured university campuses, reading excerpts from the book. All of the proceeds from the speaking tour, and the book itself, were donated to a theatrical charity.
==See also== * [[Theatre criticism]]
==External links== *http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2014/aug/17/diana-rigg-no-turn-unstoned-review-edinburgh-festival-2014 *http://www.express.co.uk/entertainment/theatre/248147/Dame-Diana-Rigg-Why-I-m-happy-to-leave-no-turn-unstoned
[[Category:1982 books]] [[Category:British books]] [[Category:Theatre criticism]]
{{theat-book-stub}}

'''Objective abstraction''' was a British art movement c. 1933-1936.
==History== Objective abstraction was a form of abstract art developed by a group of British artists in 1933. Experimentation was prevalent in [[British art]] at the time.
The main figures were [[Graham Bell (artist)|Graham Bell]], [[William Coldstream]], [[Edgar Hubert]], [[Rodrigo Moynihan]] and [[Geoffrey Tibble]].
The movement was short-lived lasting only a few years. Many of the artists involved went on to be part of the [[realism (arts)|realist]] [[Euston Road School]].
==Method== William Townsend told the [[Tate Gallery]] that 'the style originated with [[Geoffrey Tibble]] in the latter half of 1933. It was immediately taken up by [[Rodrigo Moynihan]] [...] and at the same time or shortly after by [[Edgar Hubert]]'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/hubert-painting-t06602/text-catalogue-entry|title=Stephens, Chris (1997) Edgar Hubert, Painting 1935-6: Catalogue entry, Tate website|accessdate=20 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://archives.ucl.ac.uk/DServe/dserve.exe?dsqIni=Dserve.ini&dsqApp=Archive&dsqCmd=Show.tcl&dsqSearch=RefNo==%27TOWNSEND%27&dsqDb=Catalog|title=William Townsend papers, University College London archive |accessdate=20 December 2014}}</ref> According to Townsend, early paintings by the group were derived from external objects but they became increasingly abstract.
The more abstract paintings, that came to represent the movements style, were created using improvised freely applied brushstrokes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tate.org.uk/learn/online-resources/glossary/o/objective-abstraction|title=Objective Abstraction, Tate website|accessdate=10 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/moynihan-objective-abstraction-t00172|title=Rodrigo Moynihan, artwork 'Objective Abstraction' c.1935–6, Tate Gallery|accessdate=31 October 2014}}</ref> [[Geoffrey Tibble]] described them as 'not abstracted from nature, and which made no reference to and had no associations with anything outside themselves [...] the picture was an object in its own right' (Bowness, 1960:198).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/873008?uid=2&uid=4&sid=21104397110851|title=Bowness, Alan (1960) The Paintings and Constructions of Victor Pasmore, ''The Burlington Magazine'', vol. 102, no. 168, May, pp. 198-203|accessdate=24 October 2014}}</ref>
==Exhibitions== In 1934, the exhibition ''Objective Abstractions'' was held at the [[Zwemmer Gallery]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artbiogs.co.uk/2/galleries/zwemmer-gallery|title=Zwemmer Gallery, Artist Biographies website|accessdate=10 September 2014}}</ref> showing the group's work, except Hubert's. The exhibition also included work by more representational artists, [[Ivon Hitchens]], [[Victor Pasmore]], and [[Ceri Richards]].

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=November 2006}} [[File:MUTCD W3-1.svg|thumb|US sign warning that a [[stop sign]] is ahead]] {{Writing systems sidebar}} A '''pictogram''', also called a '''pictogramme''', '''pictograph''', or simply '''picto''',Gove, Philip Babcock. (1993). ''Webster's Third New International Dictionary of the English Language Unabridged''. Merriam-Webster Inc. {{ISBN|0-87779-201-1}}. and in computer usage an '''[[Computer icon|icon]]''', is an [[ideogram]] that conveys its meaning through its pictorial resemblance to a physical object. Pictographs are often used in writing and graphic systems in which the characters are to a considerable extent pictorial in appearance. A pictogram may also be used in subjects such as leisure, tourism, and geography. Pictography is a form of [[Writing system|writing]] which uses representational, pictorial [[Drawing (manufacturing)|drawings]], similarly to [[cuneiform]] and, to some extent, [[Hieroglyph|hieroglyphic writing]], which also uses drawings as phonetic letters or [[determinative]] rhymes. Some pictograms, such as [[GHS hazard pictograms|Hazards pictograms]], are elements of [[Introduction to Automata Theory, Languages, and Computation|formal languages]]. Pictograph has a rather different meaning in the field of [[prehistoric art]], including recent art by traditional societies and then means art painted on rock surfaces, as opposed to [[petroglyph]]s; the latter are carved or incised. Such images may or may not be considered pictograms in the general sense. ==Historical== [[File:Agawa Rock, panel VIII.jpg|thumb|alt=A boat and an animal with horns, painted with red ochre|[[Ojibwa]] pictographs on cliff-face at Agawa Rock, [[Lake Superior Provincial Park]]]] Early written [[symbols]] were based on pictographs (pictures which resemble what they signify) and [[ideograms]] (symbols which represent ideas). Ancient Sumerian, Egyptian, and Chinese civilizations began to adapt such symbols to represent concepts, developing them into [[logogram|logographic writing systems]]. Pictographs are still in use as the main medium of written communication in some non-literate cultures in [[Africa]], the [[Americas]], and [[Oceania]]. Pictographs are often used as simple, pictorial, representational symbols by most contemporary cultures. [[File:Signatures from the Past.jpg|thumb|left| Several prehistoric engravings can be found around [[La Silla Observatory]].{{cite web|title=Signatures from the Past|url=https://www.eso.org/public/images/potw1705a/|website=www.eso.org|accessdate=30 January 2017}}]] Pictographs can be considered an art form, or can be considered a written language and are designated as such in [[Pre-Columbian art]], [[Native American art]], Ancient [[Mesopotamia]] and [[Painting in the Americas before Colonization]]. One example of many is the [[Rock art of the Chumash people]], part of the [[:Category:Native American history of California|Native American history of California]]. In 2011, UNESCO's World Heritage List added "[[Petroglyph]] Complexes of the Mongolian Altai, Mongolia"{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1382|title=Petroglyphic Complexes of the Mongolian Altai|first=UNESCO World Heritage|last=Centre|website=whc.unesco.org}} to celebrate the importance of the pictograms engraved in rocks. Some scientists in the field of neuropsychiatry and neuropsychology, such as Prof. Dr. [[Mario Christian Meyer]], are studying the symbolic meaning of indigenous pictograms and petroglyphs,http://unesdoc.UNESCO.org/images/0006/000678/067843F.pdf aiming to create new ways of communication between native people and modern scientists to safeguard and valorize their cultural diversity.http://www.pisad.bio.br/artigos/amazonupclose_outoftheforest.pdf == Modern uses == An early modern example of the extensive use of pictographs may be seen in the map in the London suburban timetables of the London and North Eastern Railway, 1936-1947, designed by [[George Dow]], in which a variety of pictographs was used to indicate facilities available at or near each station. Pictographs remain in common use today, serving as pictorial, representational [[signage|sign]]s, instructions, or statistical diagrams. Because of their graphical nature and fairly realistic style, they are widely used to indicate public toilets, or places such as airports and train stations. Because they are a concise way to communicate a concept to people who speak many different languages, pictograms are also used extensively at the [[Olympics]], and are redesigned for each set of games.[https://pages.uncc.edu/visualrhetoric/projects/illustration-video/olympic-pictograms/ Visual Rhetoric - Olympic Pictograms][https://mediamadegreat.com/olympic-pictograms/ Olympic Pictograms: Design through History][http://1stmuse.com/pictograms/ Olympic Games Pictograms] Pictographic writing as a modernist poetic technique is credited to [[Ezra Pound]], though French [[surrealism|surrealists]] accurately credit the [[Pacific Northwest]] [[Native Americans in the United States|American Indians]] of [[Alaska]] who introduced writing, via [[totem pole]]s, to [[North America]].Reed 2003, p. xix Contemporary artist [[Xu Bing]] created Book from the Ground, a universal language made up of pictograms collected from around the world. A Book from the Ground chat program has been exhibited in museums and galleries internationally. Pictograms are used in many areas of modern life for commodity purposes, often as a [[formal language]] (see the [[#In mathematics|In mathematics]] section). ==In mathematics== [[File:Titanic casualties.svg|thumb|300px|alt=table with boxes instead of numbers, the amounts and sizes of boxes represent amounts of people|A compound pictogram showing the breakdown of the survivors and deaths of the maiden voyage of the [[RMS Titanic]] by class and age/gender.]] In statistics, pictograms are charts in which icons represent numbers to make it more interesting and easier to understand. A key is often included to indicate what each icon represents. All icons must be of the same size, but a fraction of an icon can be used to show the respective fraction of that amount.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/skillswise/factsheet/ma37grap-e3-f-pictograms|title=Understanding pictograms|website=www.bbc.co.uk}} For example, the following table: {| class="wikitable" ! Day !! Letters sent |- | Monday || 10 |- | Tuesday || 17 |- | Wednesday || 29 |- | Thursday || 41 |- | Friday || 18 |} can be graphed as follows: {| class="wikitable sortable mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" |+ ! Day !! Letters sent |- | Monday || [[File:Email Silk.svg|alt=one envelope]] |- | Tuesday || [[File:Email Silk.svg|alt=one envelope]] [[File:Image from the Silk icon theme by Mark James half left.svg|alt=and a half]] |- | Wednesday || [[File:Email Silk.svg|alt=three envelopes]] [[File:Email Silk.svg|alt=]] [[File:Email Silk.svg|alt=]] |- | Thursday || [[File:Email Silk.svg|alt=four envelopes]] [[File:Email Silk.svg|alt=]] [[File:Email Silk.svg|alt=]] [[File:Email Silk.svg|alt=]] |- | Friday || [[File:Email Silk.svg|alt=two envelopes]] [[File:Email Silk.svg|alt=]] |} Key: [[File:Email Silk.svg|alt=one envelope]] = 10 letters As the values are rounded to the nearest 5 letters, the second icon on Tuesday is the left half of the original. ==Standardization== Pictographs can often transcend languages in that they can communicate to speakers of a number of tongues and language families equally effectively, even if the languages and cultures are completely different. This is why [[Road signs in the United States|road signs]] and similar pictographic material are often applied as global standards expected to be understood by nearly all. A standard set of pictographs was defined in the [[international standard]] ''[[ISO 7001]]: Public Information Symbols''. Other common sets of pictographs are the [[laundry symbols]] used on clothing tags and the [[GHS hazard pictograms|chemical hazard symbols]] as standardized by the [[Globally Harmonized System of Classification and Labeling of Chemicals|GHS system]]. Pictograms have been popularized in use on the [[World Wide Web|web]] and in [[software]], better known as "[[Computer icon|icon]]s" displayed on a computer screen in order to help user navigate a computer system or mobile device. ==Image gallery== File:GreatGalleryedit.jpg|[[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] Pictographs from the Great Gallery, [[Horseshoe Canyon (Utah)|Horseshoe Canyon]], [[Canyonlands National Park]] File:National Park Service sample pictographs.svg|Sample [[National Park Service]] pictographs File:Piktograf1.png|Pictograph from 1510 telling a story of coming of [[missionaries]] to [[Hispaniola]] File:Piktogramm Schwimmer an der Muenchner Olympia Schwimmhalle.JPG|Olympic village pictogram at the 1972 Munich Olympics File:Railway pictograms.jpg|[[British Rail]] passenger safety pictographs at the end of the platform at [[Meols railway station]] File:road-sign-horse.jpg|The top traffic sign warns people of horses and riders. File:Water,Rabbit,Deer.jpg|Water, rabbit, deer pictographs on a replica of an [[Aztec]] [[Stone of the Sun]] == See also == {{div col|colwidth=22em}} *[[List of symbols]] *[[List of writing systems]] (sublist for those using pictograms) *[[Emoticon]] *[[Emoji]] *[[Icon (computing)]] *[[Ideogram]] *[[Stick figure]]
In art:
*[[List of Stone Age art]] *[[Crop art]] *[[Pecked curvilinear nucleated]] *[[Petroform]] *[[Petroglyph]] *[[Rebus]] *[[Rock art]] *[[Rock art of the Chumash people]] *[[Yakima Indian Painted Rocks]] {{div col end}} ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== {{refbegin}} * [[Ishmael Reed|Reed, Ishmael]] (2003). ''From Totems to Hip-Hop: A Multicultural Anthology of Poetry Across the Americas, 1900-2002'', Ishmael Reed, ed. {{ISBN|1-56025-458-0}}. {{refend}} ==External links== {{Commons|Category:Pictograms}} {{Wiktionary}} {{refbegin}} *[http://pic-com.jp/ Pictogram & Communication: About 1,500 practical pictograms based on Design principles of pictorial symbols for communication support(JIS T 0103:2005)] *[http://capl.washjeff.edu/ CAPL:The Culturally Authentic Pictorial Lexicon, photographic illustrations of objects for multiple languages] *[http://pictopedia.jp/eng/ Pictogram Encyclopedia, The collection site of more than 500 pictograms, Pictograms are categorized, and easy to find unique pictogram] *[http://www.pictopen.com Pictopen] - Modern Pictographic Writing *[http://thenounproject.com NounProject] - Free Pictograms under open licences *[http://modernpictograms.com Modern Pictograms] - Explore word and pictogram relationships *[http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=2016+to+Babylonian Wolfram|Alpha] - Number to pictogram translator {{refend}} {{Visualization}} {{Writing systems |expanded=Ideo/Pictograms}} {{list of writing systems}} {{Prehistoric technology}} [[Category:Infographics]] [[Category:Prehistoric inscriptions| ]] [[Category:Pictograms| ]] [[Category:Rock art]] [[Category:Petroglyphs| ]] [[Category:Pre-Columbian art]] [[Category:Indigenous art]] [[Category:History of communication]] [[Category:Proto-writing]] [[Category:Statistical charts and diagrams]]

'''Poster Boy''' is a decentralized group of vandals.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/04/arts/design/04post.html?_r=0|title=Poster Boy Is Caught, or Is It a Stand-In?|date=3 February 2009|first=Randy|last=Kennedy|work=NYTimes.com|accessdate=10 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Brian Raftery|url=http://nymag.com/arts/art/profiles/50969/|title=Slice and Dice|work=New York Magazine|date=5 October 2008|accessdate=10 July 2016}}</ref> Since the beginning, Poster Boy has remained anonymous and refuse to sell or sign any original work.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Search for True Selflessness in Art Making|date=8 October 2008|work=edwardwinkleman.com|url=http://www.edwardwinkleman.com/2008/10/search-for-true-selflessness-in-art.html|accessdate=10 July 2016}}</ref> The collective's work focuses the principles of [[hip hop]], specifically the element of [[graffiti]], by limiting almost all work to improvisation.<ref name="guardian">{{cite web|title=Cut, copy and paste|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2009/jan/17/guerilla-artist-graffiti-poster-boy|first=Ben|last=Walters|date=17 January 2009|work=The Guardian|accessdate=10 July 2016 | location=London}}</ref> Using only a razor blade, Poster Boy creates satiric [[collage]]-like works created by cutting out sections of the self-adhesive advertisement posters in the platforms of [[New York City Subway]] stations, and pasting them back in different positions. Poster Boy is also referred to a 'Poster Boy movement' where other people produce similar unsigned work in the New York City subways imitating this original artist. Even after their first arrest, of Brooklyn resident Henry Matyjewicz, the collective remains active online and on the streets.<ref>{{cite web|first=Jen|last=Carlson|url=http://gothamist.com/2010/05/18/poster_boy_3.php|title=Poster Boy: Still In Jail, Still Emailing Us|date=18 May 2010|work=The Gothamist|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170227080610/http://gothamist.com/2010/05/18/poster_boy_3.php|archivedate=27 February 2017|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Poster Boy NYC on Flickr|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/posterboynyc/}}</ref>
One of Poster Boy's work is featured in [[Banksy]]'s 2010 documentary ''[[Exit Through the Gift Shop]]''.
Poster Boy's work was also included in the retrospective street art show "10 Years of Wooster Collective" at Jonathan Levine Gallery in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jonathanlevinegallery.com/?method=Exhibit.ExhibitDescriptionPast&ExhibitID=75CD4EB8-FEF4-83E0-A01FCB6F121974BB|author=Jonathan Levine Gallery|title=10 YEARS OF WOOSTER COLLECTIVE:2003—2013|accessdate=10 July 2016|date=7 August 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.artinfo.com/artintheair/2013/08/12/poster-boy-tears-it-up-at-the-wooster-collectives-10th-anniversary-exhibition/|title=Poster Boy Tears it Up at the Wooster Collective’s 10th Anniversary Exhibition|date=12 August 2013|author=Sutton, Benjamin}}</ref>
==Work== "At first, it was just something to keep me occupied while waiting on the subway."<ref name="guardian"/> "I was playing with the posters, cutting them up"<ref name="Raftery">{{cite news| author= Brian Raftery | url=http://nymag.com/arts/art/profiles/50969/ | title= Slice and Dice | work= New York Magazine | date=2008-10-05}}</ref> (he carried a razor used at work) and discovered that unlike the cardboard posters in the subway trains, the advertising posters on the subway platforms were printed on a self-adhesive material that could be stuck back down after being torn or cut out. He began to play with available images and text to create humorous "mash-ups" of advertisements. In 2008 alone, he has created over 200 manipulated underground posters in NYC subway. He compares the creation of poster "mash-ups" to [[hip hop]] "[[freestyling]]" on a microphone.<ref name="Sherwin">{{cite news | author= Brian Sherwin | url= http://gothamist.com/2009/01/23/posterboy_street_artist.php | title= Poster Boy, Street Artist (interview). | work= The Gothamist | date= 2009-01-23 | deadurl= yes | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090126151446/http://gothamist.com/2009/01/23/posterboy_street_artist.php | archivedate= 2009-01-26 | df= }}</ref> He does not have preconceived notions of what the work will be ("I don't have anything planned…go there, see something, get inspired and do the work"<ref>{{cite web|title=Poster Boy, interview in "Spending Time with Poster Boy" video, 1:44. Recorded January 2009|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=21iVQ0iXs00|via=youtube}}</ref>), but uses the available images, often in a way that relates to current events. One commentator noted: "The pieces generally have a critical edge to them, making comments on the state of society and on the advertisements themselves."<ref>{{cite web|author=PSFK Blog|title=Poster Boy: Remixing Subway Ads|date=September 25, 2008|url=http://www.psfk.com/2008/09/poster-boy-remixing-subway-ads.html}}</ref> This can be explicitly political (as his pieces on [[Sean Bell]],<ref>{{cite web|author=Poster Boy|title=''untitled (My NYPD Killed Sean Bell)'', subway poster mash-up|year=2008|url=http://jackmax2.files.wordpress.com/2008/10/2633361143_0a51089a30_m.jpg}}</ref> "IRAN = NAM",<ref>{{cite web|author=Poster Boy|title=''untitled (Ultimate Wars; Iran=Nam)'', subway poster mash-up|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/gallery/2009/jan/17/street-art-poster-boy-in-pictures?picture=341833011|via=The Guardian}}</ref> "Obama Drama,"<ref>{{cite web|author=Poster Boy|title=''untitled (Obama Drama)'', subway poster mash-up|year=2008|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/26296445@N05/3033377295/in/datetaken/|via=Flickr}}</ref> and Gaza<ref>{{cite web|author=Poster Boy|title="Gaza Simulacra," collage for magazine cover|year=2009|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/26296445@N05/3191217607/}}</ref>), or a more general send up of celebrity and corporate culture.
Poster Boy has been called the "Matisse of subway-ad mash-ups,"<ref name="Raftery" /> "a kind of anti-consumerist Zorro with a razor blade,"<ref name="NYT4-2-09" /> and "an anti-consumerist guerilla artist."<ref name="Adbusters06-02-09">{{cite web|title=Poster Boy: The 27-year-old Brooklyn artist was arrested on Saturday|work=AdBusters Blog|first=Sarah|last=Nardi|date=6 February 2009|url=http://www.adbusters.org/blogs/aesthetico/poster_boy.html}}</ref> Culture reporter Ben Walters has said of his work "Poster Boy's work straddles two boisterous artistic subcultures: [[street art]] and [[culture jamming]]."<ref name="guardian" /> Poster Boy has said of his technique, "No matter what I do to the piece, as long as I did something to those advertisements and that saturation, it's political. It's anti-media, anti–established art world."<ref name="Raftery" />
Poster Boy calls the work "A social thing, as opposed to being an artist making things for bored rich people to hang above their couch."<ref name="Raftery" /> Besides the message of the individual piece, the aspect of producing anonymous public art that other people could do is part of the work. In a video interview, he has said of his work, "I want it to be free of copyright and free of authorship, as much as possible."<ref name="Friends1">{{cite av media|title=Friends We Love ft. Poster Boy NYC :: Artist + Vigilante (video interview)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BOhOYyZL01g|via=YouTube}}</ref> "The overall goal for Poster Boy is to inspire others. I'd love to see people take up the Poster Boy model and create change within their environment."<ref name="Sherwin" /> As his fame has grown, others have begun to emulate the technique. Whether these are unconnected individuals copying one original artist, or part of the "Poster Boy model" or "movement" has not been publicly confirmed.
Poster Boy's work is transitive (usually ripped down by MTA employees) but recorded in photographs. Photos of most of his work put up on the Poster Boy photostream on the Flickr photo sharing website.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/26296445@N05/|title=Poster Boy's NYC Photostream on Flickr}}</ref>
Poster Boy has collaborated with [[Aakash Nihalani]], a street artist who uses brightly colored electrical tape to create geometric patterns, and has worked on large outdoor monochrome pieces covering illegal NPA billboards with [[Jordan Seiler]] of the Public Ad Campaign.<ref>{{cite web|author=Seiler, Jordan|title=PosterBoy Collaboration|work=Public Ad Campaign blog |date=21 November 2008|url=http://www.publicadcampaign.com/completedprojects/}}</ref>
Poster Boy's work had recently grown in scale and he has applied his technique to large billboards.<ref>{{Cite av media|title=Video: PosterBoy Deconstructs Brooklyn Billboard|time=1:04|work=The Gothamist|date=January 2009|url=http://gothamist.com/2009/01/19/video_poster_boy_deconstructs_billb.php|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090123172944/http://gothamist.com/2009/01/19/video_poster_boy_deconstructs_billb.php|archivedate=2009-01-23|df=}}</ref> He seems to have been unaware of the somewhat similar and earlier billboard work of the UK group [[Cutup]].
In March 2009, a major installation of subway advertising by the [[Museum of Modern Art]] at the Atlantic / Pacific subway stop in Brooklyn, consisting just of reproductions of works shown in MOMA, was doctored by what was claimed to be "the mysterious Poster Boy collective" along with [[Doug Jaeger]] of [[thehappycorp]]. The cutups included part of a Goodyear tire appearing to be floating with [[Claude Monet|Monet]]'s ''waterlilies''.<ref>{{cite web|author=Finch, Charlie|title=No Smiles at MOMA|work=artnet|year=2009|url=http://www.artnet.com/magazineus/features/finch/finch3-3-09.asp}}</ref>
The initial Poster Boy work was all illicit, and he claimed "I don't want to make any money off of it. I don't want to bring it into the galleries.".<ref name="Friends1"/> However, after his arrest in January 2009 his work has been shown in galleries, including a one-person show in Eastern District Brooklyn, April 3–26, 2009. He was also included in the group show, Razors, Tape, Glass, at [[Jajo Gallery]] in Newark New Jersey. This move has been criticized in the street art blogs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://animalnewyork.com/2009/04/poster-boy-should-remain-underground/|date=9 April 2009|title=POSTER BOY SHOULD REMAIN UNDERGROUND|author=Turco, Bucky|work=ANIMAL|accessdate=10 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://gawker.com/5211860/is-poster-boy-still-good-in-a-gallery|date=14 April 2009|title=Is Poster Boy Still Good in a Gallery?|last=Nolan|first=Hamilton|work=Gawker}}</ref>
==Legal issues== Poster Boy's cutting and pasting of subway advertisements is illegal. Previously their work had been noted by the MTA police, but did not seem a high priority for them. "Vandalism of our property is illegal, and we prosecute to the fullest extent of the law," spokesperson Aaron Donovan told reporter Brian Raftery. "That being said, the problem to date has been minimal."<ref>{{cite web|title=Quoted by Brian Raftery, 2008|url=http://nymag.com/arts/art/profiles/50969/}}</ref> He has had several brushes with the law, but on occasions transit police have let him go. On January 30, 2009, while attending a benefit for Friends We Love artist's video documentaries, a person thought to be Poster Boy was arrested by undercover police agents waiting for him. This "Poster Boy" was charged with two misdemeanor counts of criminal mischief and went before a Judge on February 9, 2009.<ref name ="NYT4-2-09">{{cite news| author= Randy Kennedy | url=http://nytimes.com/2009/02/04/arts/design/04post.html?8dpc | title= Poster Boy is caught, or is it a stand-in? | work= New York Times | date=2009-02-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | author= Billy Parker | url= http://gothamist.com/2009/01/31/nypd_rolls_up_on_posterboy.php | title= NYPD Rolls Up on Poster Boy | work= The Gothamist | date= 2009-01-31 | deadurl= yes | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090203025844/http://gothamist.com/2009/01/31/nypd_rolls_up_on_posterboy.php | archivedate= 2009-02-03 | df= }}</ref><ref name="NYPost17-1-09">{{cite news| author= Ginsberg, Alex | url=http://www.nypost.com/seven/02102009/news/regionalnews/a_defiant_hell_154381.htm | title= A Defiant 'Hell | work= New York Post | date=2009-02-10}}</ref>
At the hearing, Poster Boy member Henry Matyjewicz, 27, rejected a plea bargain, where he would plead guilty to a misdemeanor charge of criminal mischief, and perform 100 hours of "community service." His lawyer, Kerry Gotlib, said his Mr. Matyjewicz was "innocent of the charges". Mr. Matyjewicz is scheduled to appear back in court in April. If the case goes to a trial the top penalties for the charges could be jail for up to one year.<ref name="NYPost17-1-09" /> However, on December 16, 2009, Matyjewicz pleaded guilty to the offenses. In exchange, the judge agreed to vacate the felony provided Matyjewicz served 210 hours of community service. Once completed, he would get three years' probation.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://blogs.wsj.com/metropolis/2010/05/10/in-a-sharp-turnabout-poster-boy-sentenced-to-jail/ | work=The Wall Street Journal | first=Nikki | last=Waller | title=Poster Boy Loses Plea Deal, Is Sentenced to Jail | date=May 10, 2010}}</ref>
Sometime around January 2009, Poster Boy's underground fame became such that there seemed to be several imitators, and his idea of having others "take up the Poster Boy model" seemed to be catching on. There even seems to be some confusion over whether the Poster Boy, arrested on January 30, 2009, was the same Poster Boy who initiated the subway collages, or a "legal" above ground stand in. ''The New York Times'' reports a call from Poster Boy saying the man who was arrested "is one of the many individuals who believe in the Poster Boy 'movement'"<ref name="NYT4-2-09" /> The [[Adbusters]] website notes that "Sources close to the artist maintain that there are, in fact, multiple 'Poster Boys' presently engaged in the project."<ref name="Adbusters06-02-09" /> In an interview after the arrest, Henry Matyjewicz has said that "Henry is an artist just inspired by what's going on with the Poster Boy movement."<ref>{{cite news| author= Matt Harvey | url=http://www.nypress.com/article-19432-who-is-poster-boy.html| title=Who Is Poster Boy? | work=New York Press| date=2009-02-18 | accessdate=2009-02-22}}</ref>
Whatever the case may be, Matyjewicz (who his lawyer, Kerry Gotlib, has admitted in court and to the media as being THE "Poster Boy"<ref>{{cite news| url=https://blogs.wsj.com/metropolis/2010/05/10/in-a-sharp-turnabout-poster-boy-sentenced-to-jail/ | work=The Wall Street Journal | first=Nikki | last=Waller | title=Poster Boy Loses Plea Deal, Is Sentenced to Jail | date=May 10, 2010}}{{qn|date=April 2012}}</ref>) continued to have run-ins with the law. On December 16, 2009, the very day he pleaded guilty in exchange for community service, Matyjewicz was arrested for turnstile-jumping allegedly on account of illegally using a discounted student [[MetroCard (New York City)#Student MetroCards|MetroCard]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/brooklyn/subway_ad_slicer_cuts_loose_again_sVFbhZsN69Uj4SU505EGuJ | work=New York Post | first=Alex | last=Ginsberg | title=Subway-ad slicer 'cuts loose' again | date=January 27, 2010}}</ref> Then, on January 22, 2010, while still on said probation, Matyjewicz was once more arrested for slicing up posters. While the DA was pressing for jail time on account of said arrest, due to a technicality, Matyjewicz was to receive only probation.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/brooklyn/poster_boy_dodges_jail_on_judge_7sfh5BSPx0V7y9Zy7XcuuL?CMP=OTC-rss&FEEDNAME=#ixzz0nFTPUIb4 | work=New York Post | first=Alex | last=Ginsberg | title=Poster Boy dodges jail on judge's goof | date=May 7, 2010}}</ref> On May 10, 2010, after skipping out on his May 6 court date, Matyjewicz (who had been expecting to be placed on probation again due an earlier court ruling) appeared in a Brooklyn court and was instead sentenced to 11 months' incarceration at [[Rikers Island]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://animalnewyork.com/2010/poster-boy-sentenced-to-11-months-in-jail/#comments | title=POSTER BOY SENTENCED TO 11 MONTHS IN JAIL | work=ANIMAL | date=May 10, 2010 | accessdate=July 10, 2016 | author=Turco, Bucky}}</ref> Matyjewicz got out of jail on appeal of the sentence after 13 days.<ref name="brooklyneagle.com">{{cite web | url=http://www.brooklyneagle.com/?category_id=4&id=38163 | title=Brooklyn Daily Eagle | work=Brooklyn Daily Eagle | accessdate=July 10, 2016}}</ref> In an opinion dated January 25, 2011, the [[New York Supreme Court, Appellate Division|Second Department of the NY Supreme Court's Appellate Division]] sustained the appeal and vacated the trial court's decision and order of incarceration.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nycourts.gov/reporter/3dseries/2011/2011_00535.htm | title=The People of the State of New York, Respondent, v Henry Matyjewicz, Appellant. | work=NYCOURTS.GOV | accessdate=July 10, 2016}}</ref> The appellate court remanded the case to the trial court (but before a difference judge) for resentencing in accordance with the original, negotiated plea deal of just probation and community service.

[http://www.edwardwinkleman.com/2008/10/search-for-true-selflessness-in-art.html "The Search for True Selflessness in Art Making"], 8 October 2008. *Randy Kennedy. [http://nytimes.com/2009/02/04/arts/design/04post.html?8dpc "Poster Boy Is Caught, or Is It a Stand-In?"] ''New York Times'', 4 February 2009. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090126151446/http://gothamist.com/2009/01/23/posterboy_street_artist.php "Poster Boy, Street Artist" (interview)]. ''The Gothamist''. January 23, 2009. *[http://www.publicadcampaign.com/2008/10/poster-boy-informal-interview.html "Poster Boy Informal Interview" with Jordan Seiler, Public Ad Campaign]. October 2008. *[http://www.myartspace.com/blog/2009/01/art-space-talk-poster-boy.html "Art Space Talk: Poster Boy" interview with Brian Sherwin on the MyArtSpace Bolg]. January 29, 2009.
Videos: *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OP1hXTlQXhc Friends We Love :: 120 Seconds w/ Poster Boy NYC" video monologue, 2:00.] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iFdIy6hpZus "Poster Boy NYC Art" Fan compilation video, 3:12.] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V4EGXunbV5E "Posterboy NYC Subway Art" Fan compilation video, 1:46.] *[http://vimeo.com/2308257 "Poster Boy In Action" Video by Animalmagazine, 1:25. Posted on Vimeo, December 2008.] *[http://www.chiefmag.com/blog/?p=6349 Jacqueline Lewis, Editor of Chief Magazine, talks to Poster Boy on video about his work]

{{ref improve|date=March 2013}} {{update|date=April 2014}} The '''Pub Design Awards (PDA)''' are an annual [[award]]s, established in 1983 and hosted by [[Campaign for Real Ale|CAMRA]] in association with [[English Heritage]] and the [[Victorian Society]], that are given to exceptional [[pub]]s in the [[United Kingdom|UK]] that have been newly built/converted or have recently undergone building/conservation work. ==Categories== The awards cover 4 Categories: #'''New Build''' ''(For newly constructed pubs)'' #'''Conversion of existing buildings to pub use''' ''(For use of a building that had not previously been a pub)'' #'''Refurbishment of existing public houses''' ''(For recently refurbished pubs. The final interior must suit the era of the building and enhance the 'feel' of the pub)'' #'''The ''English Heritage'' Award for conservation''' ''(For pubs that have retained much of their original design and/or decor, and have recently had conservation work to improve the overall condition of the interior.)'' There is also a fifth award which is given independently of the above categories and cannot be entered directly; the '''Joe Goodwin Conservation Award''', sometimes known as '' '[[Joe Goodwin]] Award for best 'Street-Corner Local' ''. This is chosen from all entries, not just winners of other categories. Any pub can only enter one category, entries may be from anywhere in the [[British Isles]]. Anyone can enter a pub for the awards. ==Entry== [[Photograph]]s and a typed description(Max. 2 A4 sheets) of the interior and exterior and what work was completed are required for entry, as are drawings of the interior plan and location map of the pub. To qualify, the work must have been finished between 1 January and 31 December of the year before, e.g. For ''2007'', the work on the pub must have been completed sometime in ''2006''. ==Judging== Judging takes place initially by shortlisting, after which the selection will be visited, the panel comprises members of the [[CAMRA Pubs Group]] along with conservation experts and architects outside ''CAMRA''. Not every award is given every year(depending on the entries), but there are often mentions for highly commended pubs, and some years there are joint winners when there are a number of exceptional pubs in particular categories. The winners receive a plaque which can be displayed publicly in the pub, permanently. ==Winners== Where the entry reads ''None Awarded'', this means no award was given in that category for that year, even though there may be 'Highly Commended' pubs in that category(which are not listed here). ''None listed'', this means there was no information about that particular award. Sources: [https://web.archive.org/web/20110518195143/http://www.camra.org.uk/page.aspx?o=pubdesignawards CAMRA website - PDA winners list]; ''What's Brewing'' (Newspaper of CAMRA), Issue: April 2007, Article: ''Better pubs by design''.. {| border=1 ! !Colspan=5 |Award |- !Year !''New Build'' !''Conversion'' !''Refurbishment'' !''Conservation'' !''Joe Goodwin Award'' |- |2008[http://www.camra.org.uk/page.aspx?o=305106 CAMRA Press Release - Pub Design Awards 2008] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090711171019/http://www.camra.org.uk/page.aspx?o=305106 |date=11 July 2009 }} (Accessed 30 June 2009) |Zero Degrees, [[Reading, Berkshire|Reading]], [[Berkshire]] |Unknown |''Joint Winners:''
* [[Princess Louise (pub)|Princess Louise]], [[High Holborn]], London * Castle Inn, [[Bradford on Avon]], [[Wilts]] |Unknown |Unknown |- |2007 |The Black Horse Inn, [[Walcote, Leicestershire|Walcote]], [[Leicestershire]] |The Tobie Norris, [[Stamford, Lincolnshire|Stamford]], [[Lincolnshire]] |The Weaver Hotel, [[Runcorn]], [[Cheshire]] |The Weaver Hotel |None Awarded |- |2006 |None Awarded |The Works, [[Sowerby Bridge]], [[West Yorkshire|W. Yorkshire]] |Prince of Wales, [[Herne Bay, Kent|Herne Bay]], [[Kent]] |Three Pigeons, [[Halifax, West Yorkshire|Halifax]], [[West Yorkshire|W. Yorkshire]] |Joint: *Prince of Wales, [[Herne Bay, Kent|Herne Bay]], [[Kent]] *Three Pigeons, [[Halifax, West Yorkshire|Halifax]], [[West Yorkshire|W. Yorkshire]] |- |2005 | | | | | |- |2004 |Zero Degrees, [[Bristol]] |The Yorkshire Terrier, [[York]] |The Racecourse, Lower Kersal, [[City of Salford|Salford]] |Prestoungrange Gothenburg, [[Prestonpans]], [[Scotland]] |The Yarborough, [[Brigg]], [[Lincolnshire]] |- |2003 |Not awarded |Smiths of Bourne, [[Lincolnshire]] |Wortley Almshouses, [[Peterborough]] |The Bell Inn, [[Nottingham]] |None listed |- |2002 |Manor Barn Farm, [[Southfleet]], [[Kent]] |Gatekeeper, Westgate Street, [[Cardiff]], [[Wales]] |The Test Match, [[West Bridgford]], [[Nottinghamshire]] |The Bath Hotel, [[Sheffield]] |Holt’s Railway, [[Didsbury]], [[Greater Manchester]] |- |2001 |None Awarded |Porterhouse, [[London]] |Joint: *Burton Bridge Brewery Tap, [[Burton on Trent]] *Thomson’s Bar, [[Edinburgh]] |Bull & Butcher, near [[Henley on Thames]] |Merchants Arms, Bristol |- |2000 |None Awarded |Sedge Lynn, [[Manchester]] |None Awarded |Phoenix, York |The Monkey, [[Crewe]] |- |1999 |None Awarded |Joint: *Billiard Hall, [[West Bromwich]] *Half Moon, Mile End Road, [[London]] |Dispensary, [[Liverpool]] |None Awarded |Dispensary, Liverpool |- |} ==See also== * [[National Pub of the Year]] * [[Heritage pub]] * [[List of public house topics]] ==References== {{Reflist}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070609062540/http://www.camra.org.uk/page.aspx?o=181094 Pub Awards Page - CAMRA] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070924182124/http://www.hxcalderdalecamra.org.uk/CAMRA%20Pub%20Design%20Awards.htm Halifax & Calderdale CAMRA - PDA Info] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070926234646/http://www.camra.org.uk/download.aspx?o=245927 Awards Entry Form (PDF)] *''What's Brewing'' (Newspaper of CAMRA), April 2007, Article: ''Better pubs by design''. {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}} [[Category:Architecture awards]] [[Category:Design awards]] [[Category:British awards]] [[Category:Pubs in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Interior design]] [[Category:Hospitality industry awards]] [[Category:Annual events in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:1983 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Awards established in 1983]]
