revision.text:
{{no footnotes|date=August 2015}}
'''Public folklore''' is the term for the work done by [[folkloristics|folklorists]] in public settings in the [[United States]] and [[Canada]] outside of universities and colleges, such as arts councils, [[museums]], [[folklife festivals]], radio stations, etc. The term is actually short for ''"public sector folklore"'' and was first used by members of the [[American Folklore Society]] in the early 1970s. [[Archie Green]] is generally credited as the founder of the public folklore movement, although his work builds on that of [[Ben Botkin]] and [[Alan Lomax]], going back as far as the 1930s. (They called their work "[[applied folklore]]," a related but distinct paradigm.)
The birth of public folklore can be traced back to the creation of the [[American Folklife Center]] at the [[Library of Congress]] in 1970, by an act of [[Congress of the United States|Congress]], sponsored by Sen. [[Ralph Yarborough]] (D-TX) and written by Green and then-Senate aide [[Jim Hightower]]. Other national programs were later established at the [[Smithsonian Institution]] and the [[National Endowment for the Arts]] (NEA), where prominent folklorists such as [[Ralph Rinzler]], [[Alan Jabbour]], and [[Bess Lomax Hawes]] worked. Funding programs were also established in the 1970s and 1980s in over 40 state arts councils, and these facilitated the eventual creation or funding of major non-profit centers for [[folklife]] documentation and presentation, such as [[City Lore]] and the [[Center for Traditional Music and Dance]] in New York, [[Texas Folklife Resources]], [[Northwest Folklife]], the [[Western Folklife Center]], and the [[Philadelphia Folklore Project]].
Public folklorists are engaged with the documentation, preservation, and presentation of traditional forms of [[folk art]]s, [[craft]], [[folk music]], and other genres of traditional [[folklife]]. In later years, public folklorists have also become involved in economic and community development projects.
Each year, some 15 outstanding American folk artists and performers are awarded [[National Heritage Fellowship]]s from the NEA for their lifetime achievement. Some more widely known awardees over the years have included [[John Lee Hooker]], [[B.B. King]], [[Clifton Chenier]], [[Earl Scruggs]], [[Michael Flatley]], [[Shirley Caesar]], [[Albertina Walker]], [[Carter Family|Janette Carter]], [[Koko Taylor]], [[Brownie McGhee]], [[Sonny Terry]], [[Jean Ritchie]], [[Sunnyland Slim]], [[Lydia Mendoza]], [[Boozoo Chavis]], [[Zakir Hussain (musician)|Zakir Hussain]], [[Helen Cordero]], [[Margaret Tafoya]], [[Santiago Jiménez, Jr.]], [[John Cephas]], [[Bois Sec Ardoin]], [[Mick Moloney]], [[Clarence Fountain]] [[Five Blind Boys of Alabama|& the Blind Boys]], [[Esther Martinez]], and the [[Dixie Hummingbirds]].
The Smithsonian Institution features the [[Smithsonian Folklife Festival]] every June and July which attracts upwards of two million people to hear live performances and view demonstrations of traditional crafts.
Public folklorists also work in "folk arts in the schools" programs, presenting master traditional artists to primary and secondary schools in demonstrations and residencies. They develop apprenticeship programs to foster the teaching of traditional arts by recognized masters. They also present traditional music on radio programs such as ''[[American Routes]]'' on [[Public Radio International]]. Occasionally they produce [[documentary film]]s on aspects of traditional arts; Smithsonian folklorist [[Marjorie Hunt]] won an [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] for her 1984 [[Academy Award for Documentary Short Subject|short documentary]] film ''[[The Stone Carvers (film)|The Stone Carvers]]'' about the carvers at the [[National Cathedral]] in Washington, D.C.
== Sources and further reading == *{{cite book |editor1-last= Baron |editor1-first= Robert |editor2-first= Nicholas R. |editor2-last= Spitzer |title= Public Folklore |location= Washington |publisher= Smithsonian Institution Press |date= 1992 |isbn= 9781934110409}} * {{cite book |editor-last= Feintuch |editor-first= Burt |title= Conservation of Culture: Folklorists and the Public Sector |location= Lexington |publisher= University Press of Kentucky |date= 1988 |hdl= 2027/heb.05637.0001.001}} * {{cite book |authorlink= Archie Green |last= Green |first= Archie |title= Torching the Fink Books: And Other Essays on Vernacular Culture |location= Chapel Hill |publisher= University of North Carolina Press |date= 2001 |isbn= 0807849200 }} * {{cite book |editor-last= Hufford |editor-first= Mary |title= Conserving Culture: A New Discourse on Heritage |location= Champaign |publisher= University of Illinois Press |date= 1994 |isbn= 978-0252063541}}
== External links == * [https://www.loc.gov/folklife American Folklife Center] at [[Library of Congress|LOC]] * [http://arts.gov/honors/heritage Heritage Fellowships] at [[National Endowment for the Arts|NEA]] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050714060703/http://www.folklife.si.edu/index.html Center for Folklife and Cultural Heritage] at [[Smithsonian Institution]] * [[Culture of New York City|NYC]] ** [http://www.citylore.org/ City Lore] ** [http://www.ctmd.org/ Center for Traditional Music and Dance (CTMD)] * [http://www.culturalpartnerships.org Institute for Cultural Partnerships], Harrisburg * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051127113948/http://www.folkculture.org/ Fund for Folk Culture], Santa Fe * [http://www.dafos.dk The Danish Folklore Archives]
[[Category:Folklore]] [[Category:Folklorists]] [[Category:Public sphere|Folklore]]

page.title: Reverend Billy and the Church of Stop Shopping

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2018}} [[File:Day 40 Occupy Wall Street October 25 2011 Shankbone 19.JPG|thumb|right|Reverend Billy at [[Occupy Wall Street]], where he performed in support of the movement.]]
'''Reverend Billy and the Church of Stop Shopping''' is a radical performance community based in New York City. The Stop Shopping Choir is accompanied by a comic preacher, Reverend Billy. The philosophy of the Church of Stop Shopping surrounds the imminent "Shopocalypse", which assumes the end of humanity will come about through manic [[consumerism]].<ref name=mcclish> {{Cite journal|last=McClish|first=Carmen L|title=Activism based in embarrassment: The anti-consumption spirituality of the Reverend Billy|journal=Liminalities: A Journal of Performance Studies|volume=5.2 (2009)|pages=1-20}}</ref>
The Stop Shopping Choir accompanies Reverend Billy and stages [[Guerrilla theatre|guerrilla theater]] style actions, singing on the property of the [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]] stores,<ref name=burke> {{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/monteburke/2011/04/21/reverend-billy-and-his-crusade-against-consumerism/2/|title=Reverend Billy and His Crusade Against Consumerism|last=Burke|first=Monte|date=April 21, 2011|work=Forbes|access-date=October 5, 2017|dead-url=}}</ref> [[Monsanto]] facilities,<ref name=burke/> and [[Trump Tower]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/the-activists-who-are-staging-acts-of-protest-inside-trump-tower|title=The Activists Who Are Staging Protest in Trump Tower.|last=Moynihan|first=Colin|date=June 14, 2017|work=The New Yorker|access-date=October 5, 2017|dead-url=}}</ref> among others. They are often considered part of the [[Culture Jamming]] movement.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Like moths to a flame: culture jamming and the global spectacle.|last=Wettergren|first=Åsa|work=Representing Resistance: Media, Civil Disobedience, and the Global Justice Movement|publisher=Praeger|year=2003|editor-last=Opel|editor-first=Andrew|location=Westport, Conn.|pages=27-43|editor-last2=Pompper|editor-first2=Donnalyn}}</ref>
The group uses the content from their direct actions to create songs that are performed on concert stages and in cabarets. The director of these shows is church co-founder Savitri D. The music director is Nehemiah Luckett. Reverend Billy and the Stop Shopping Choir routinely perform at [[Joe's Pub]] at [[The Public Theater]] in [[New York City]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/lypsinka-reverend-billy-and-tori-scott-coming-to-joes-pub-may-11-18|title=John Epperson, Reverend Billy, and Tori Scott Coming to Joe's Pub May 11–18|last=Viagas|first=Robert|date=October 5, 2017|website=|dead-url=}}</ref>
==Origins of Reverend Billy==
[[File:RevBilly1.jpg|thumb|left|Reverend Billy attempting to exorcise bad loans and toxic assets from the Bank of America ATM in Union Square, New York City, 2009]]
The character of Reverend Billy was developed in the early 1990s by actor and playwright, William Talen. His family was Dutch Calvinist,<ref name=kalb>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/02/27/arts/spring-theater-visions-america-downtown-gospel-according-reverend-billy.html|title=The Downtown Gospel According to Reverend Billy|last=Kalb|first=Jonathan|date=February 27, 2000|work=The New York Times|access-date=October 5, 2017|dead-url=}}</ref> from the [[Christian Reformed Church in North America|Christian Reformed Church]], a conservative sect concentrated in Holland and Grand Rapids, Michigan. The precepts of this kind of [[Christianity]] were the basis for Dutch [[Afrikaners]] system of [[Apartheid]] in South Africa.{{cn|date=November 2018}}
Talen grew up in small towns throughout Minnesota, South Dakota and Wisconsin. He left home at 16, moving east with Charles and Patricia Gaines, a writer and painter who encouraged him as an artist. Talen began to perform his poems and stories, hitch-hiking from Philadelphia to New York to San Francisco.<ref name=jacobs> {{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/profile-of-william-talen-better-known-as-reverend-billy-2015-2?r=UK&IR=T|title=The craziest thing about this legendary singing, anti-corporate preacher is that he isn't real|last=Jacobs|first=Harrison|date=February 4, 2015|work=Business Insider|access-date=March 29, 2018|dead-url=}}</ref>
Talen's chief collaborator in developing the Reverend Billy character was the Reverend Sidney Lanier, a cousin of [[Tennessee Williams]].<ref name=kalb/> Lanier was vicar of The [[Church of St. Clement Mary Hofbauer|St. Clement's]] in the 1960s, an Episcopal Church in [[Hell's Kitchen, Manhattan|Hell's Kitchen]] in [[Manhattan]].<ref name=kalb/> In an effort to increase attendance at St. Clement's, Lanier had torn out the altar and pews, inviting actors to perform scenes from plays by Tennessee Williams and Terrence McNally, and founding founding the American Place Theater. Lanier described Talen as "more of a preacher with a gift for social prophecy than an actor.<nowiki>''</nowiki><ref name=kalb/> In the early 1990s Talen moved with Lanier to New York City from the San Francisco Bay Area, branding his act as a "new kind of American preacher"<ref name=jacobs/>
The Reverend Billy character debuted on the sidewalk at Times Square in 1998, outside the Disney Store, where he proclaimed Mickey Mouse to be the anti-Christ.<ref name=kalb/> He was arrested multiple times outside the Disney Store, where he duct-tapped Mickey Mouse to a cross.<ref name=Kasperkevic>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/nov/27/reverend-billy-church-of-stop-shopping-black-friday|title=The Church of Stop Shopping doesn't pull punches on its return to New York.|last=Kasperkevic|first=Jana|date=November 27, 2015|work=The Guardian|access-date=October 8, 2017|dead-url=}}</ref> Reverend Billy's sermons decried the evils of [[consumerism]] and the racism of sweatshop labor, and what Talen saw as the loss of neighborhood spirit in [[Rudy Giuliani|Rudolph Giuliani]]'s New York.<ref name=jacobs/>
The Reverend Billy character isn't so much a parody of a preacher, as a preacher motif used to blur the lines between performance and religious experience. "It's definitely a church service," Talen explained to ''Altnernet'', but, he added, it's "a political rally, it's theater, it's all three, it's none of them."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.alternet.org/story/29476/the_reluctant_religion_of_reverend_billy|title=The Reluctant Religion of Reverend Billy|last=Tytel|first=Brad|date=December 12, 2005|work=Alternet|access-date=April 1, 2018|dead-url=}}</ref> Alisa Solomon, the theater critic at the [[The Village Voice|Village Voice]], said of Reverend Billy's persona, "The collar is fake, the calling is real."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.villagevoice.com/2000/03/14/never-can-say-good-buy/|title=Never Can Say Good Buy|last=Solomon|first=Alisa|date=March 14, 2000|work=The Village Voice|access-date=October 8, 2017|dead-url=}}</ref> Along with the Church of Stop Shopping, they have been referred to by academics as "performance activism,"<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Perucci|first=Tony|year=2009|title=What the Fuck is That?: The Poetics of Ruptural Performance|journal=Liminalities: A Journal of Performance Studies|volume=5.3|pages=1-18}}</ref> "carnivalesque protest,"<ref name="mcclish" /> and "commercial disobedience."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/08/22/magazine/reverend-billy-s-unholy-war.html|title=Reverend Billy's Unholy War.|last=Dee|first=Jonathan|date=August 22, 2004|work=The New York Times Magazine|dead-url=}}</ref>
==Savitri D, church co-founder and theatrical director==
Savitri D (née Durkee) is the co-founder and director of the Church of Stop Shopping, as well as Talen's partner.<ref name=kolbert>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2014/05/19/buzzkill-2|title=Buzzkill|last=Kolbert|first=Elizabeth|date=May 19, 2014|work=The New Yorker|access-date=March 29, 2018|dead-url=}}</ref> She was born in [[Taos, New Mexico]] in 1972. She was raised at [[Lama Foundation|The Lama Foundation]], one of the earliest and longest lasting intentional spiritual communities in the US, founded by her parents, Steven and Barbara Durkee.<ref>Banner, Lois W. "Finding Fran: History and Memory in the Lives of Two Women", Columbia University Press, 1998, p. 173. {{ISBN|0-231-11216-5}}</ref>
Savitri D began dancing and performing at the University of Montana, studied at the [[Merce Cunningham]] Dance Company, and co-founded a dance collective called The Zen Monkey Project.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.zenmonkeyproject.com/history/|title=History of Past Performances|website=Zen Monkey Project|dead-url=}}</ref> After moving to New York City in 1997, she staged her play SKY/NO SKY at 57 Walker Street<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://franklinfurnace.org/goings_on/recent_goings_on/2003/03_03_13.php|title=Franklin Furnace's Goings On|date=March 13, 2003|website=Franklin's Furnace|dead-url=|access-date=March 31, 2018}}</ref>.
In 2000, she was a producer at The Culture Project, a theater in the [[East Village, Manhattan|East Village]], where Talen was staging early Reverend Billy performances.<ref name=jacobs/> She took over direction of The Church of Stop Shopping performances from the dramatist Tony Torn<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.theatermania.com/new-york-city-theater/reviews/03-2000/reverend-billy_350.html|title=Reviews: Reverend Billy|last=Josh|first=Godfrey|date=March 17, 2000|work=Theater Mania|access-date=March 31, 2018|dead-url=}}</ref> in the aftermath of the [[September 11 attacks]] in 2001, and married Talen the next year.<ref name=jacobs/>
Under Savitri D's leadership, the Church won the Alpert Award for Theater<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://herbalpertawards.org/artist/2010/bill-talen|title=The Herb Alpert Award in the Arts|website=The Herb Alpert Awards|dead-url=}}</ref> and the Edwin Booth Award<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gc.cuny.edu/Page-Elements/Academics-Research-Centers-Initiatives/Doctoral-Programs/Theatre/Doctoral-Theatre-Students-Association-(DTSA)/Booth-Award|title=Booth Award, Previous Award Recipients|website=The Graduate Center, CUNY|dead-url=}}</ref> from the [[City University of New York]].
==The Stop Shopping Choir==
The Stop Shopping Choir is a 35-member ensemble that performs an array of original gospel songs in theater performances and alongside Reverend Billy in public spaces during campaigns.<ref name=revbilly.com>{{Cite web|url=http://www.revbilly.com/about_the_stop_shopping_choir|title=About The Stop Shopping Choir|website=revbilly.com|dead-url=|access-date=April 2, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/16/nyregion/reverend-billy-brings-a-new-sermon-to-joes-pub.html|title=Reverend Billy Brings a New Sermon to Joe's Pub|last=Lee|first=A.C.|date=May 15, 2014|work=The New York Times|access-date=April 2, 2018|dead-url=}}</ref> The choir began accompanying Talen's sermons at concert shows shortly after the [[September 11 attacks]], adding a musical influence to Reverend Billy performances.<ref name=jacobs/> Led by musical director Nehemiah Luckett,<ref name=revbilly.com/> the choir members are volunteers who rehearse weekly at the Lower Eastside Girl's Club in the [[East Village, Manhattan|East Village]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/if-monsanto-loses-its-name-what-will-its-haters-have-left-to-hate-1477402968|title=If Monsanto Loses Its Name, What Will Its Haters Have Left to Hate?|last=Bunge|first=Jacob|date=October 15, 2016|work=The Wall Street Journal|access-date=April 2, 2018|dead-url=}}</ref>
The Choir often write songs that draw attention to the environmental and consumerist campaigns championed by the Church of Stop Shopping. They have accompanied Talen into the lobbies of multinational banks such as JP Morgan Chase or research facilities belonging to Monsanto, dressed as golden toads and honeybees, singing songs in support of the day's sermon. One of their best-known songs is The First Amendment, an incantation of the 1st Amendment of the [[United States Constitution]], sung rapturously by soprano Laura Newman.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.revbilly.com/the_first_amendment_song|title=The First Amendment Song|website=revbilly.com|dead-url=}}</ref>
==Direct Action Campaigns==
In addition to protest performances throughout a given year, Reverend Billy and the Church of Stop Shopping have organized various campaigns focused on consumerist or environmental issues, often highlighting a particular company they feel best symbolizes the issue. The group stage actions in public spaces near the targets of their actions, or in the lobbies, halls, and plazas of the building owned by the companies they protest. Their sermons and songs routinely draw the attention of police and security forces assigned to those spaces, leading to arrests and significant media coverage. Talen and Savitri D have been arrested more than 50 times during their actions, though their charges are almost always reduced or dropped.<ref name=jacobs/>
===Early campaigns=== Reverend Billy and the Church of Stop Shopping staged numerous actions around New York City in their formative years. In 2000, after performing a Christmas show the [[The New School|New School]]'s Tishman Auditorium, Reverend Billy led the congregation and members of the audience from the stage to the [[Edgar Allan Poe House (Manhattan)|Poe House]] on West 3rd Street in Manhattan's [[West Village]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/merry-christmas-rev-billy-performance-preacher-hosts-poe-service-dec-16-com-93856|title=Merry Christmas, Rev. Billy: Performance Preacher Hosts Poe Service Dec. 16|last=Ehren|first=Christine|date=December 16, 2000|work=Playbill|access-date=April 23, 2018}}</ref> There, the Reverend held a protest reading of "[[The Raven]]" atop the scaffolding over the soon-to-be-demolished home where [[Edgar Allan Poe|Edgar Allen Poe]] had finished writing the famous poem. After the reading, Talen was arrested and jailed.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.playloud.org/archiveandstore/en/dvd/60-reverend-billy.html|title=Reverend Billy & The Church of Stop Shopping|last=Post|first=Dietmar|last2=Palacios|first2=Lucía|year=2002|website=playloud!|dead-url=}}</ref>
After [[September 11 attacks|September 11]], the Church and Choir met routinely in the [[PATH (rail system)|Path Station]] near [[World Trade Center site|Ground Zero]] and sang the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment to the U.S. Constitution]] into their phones as commuters passed by. The crowd of singers sometimes reached up to 200 participants.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/He-s-a-preacher-of-sorts-who-has-found-his-2764879.php|title=He's a preacher -- of sorts -- who has found his calling: rooting out the evils of consumerism, block by entertaining block|last=Ganahl|first=Jane|date=April 24, 2004|work=San Francisco Chronicle|access-date=April 23, 2018}}</ref>
On June 29, 2007, just before the start of the monthly [[Critical Mass (cycling)|Critical Mass bike]] ride, Reverend Billy and Savitri D recited the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] repeatedly to police officers through a megaphone in Manhattan's Union Square. Reverend Billy was arrested on charges of second-degree harassment.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/26/nyregion/26billy.html|title=A Street Performer Crusades for the First Amendment|last=Hartocollis|first=Anemona|date=September 26, 2007|work=The New York Times|access-date=April 23, 2018}}</ref> The civil liberties lawyer [[Norman Siegel]] defended Reverend Billy in court, saying "Reverend Billy has a First Amendment right to recite the First Amendment."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/01/nyregion/01billy.html|title=A Pretend Preacher, a Real Arrest and a Debate About Free Speech|last=Wilensky-Lanford|first=Ethan|date=July 1, 2007|work=The New York Times|access-date=April 23, 2018}}</ref>
===Starbucks=== The Church of Stop Shopping staged a series of actions across the country from 2002 to 2008, protesting against what they call Starbucks company's enactment of "fake bohemia." Reverend Billy and the singers tried to "exorcise the demon of cookie-cutter capitalism" from its cash registers, by laying hands on the register, weeping, and harmonizing.<ref name=Kasperkevic/>
The [[Starbucks]] coffee chain has been a frequent target of the Church's actions, due to displacement of small local businesses,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.urbandisplacement.org/case-studies/ucla#section-91|title=Impact of Big Businesses in Chinatown|last=Macedo|first=Edber|last2=Fang|first2=Jimmy|date=July 1, 2014|website=UCLA Case Studies|dead-url=|access-date=November 12, 2017|last3=Le|first3=Thomas|last4=Ong|first4=Paul M.}}</ref> [[union busting]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/zp-heller/spilling-the-beans-about_b_205497.html|title=Spilling the Beans About Starbucks' Union-Busting Tactics|last=Heller|first=ZP|date=May 25, 2011|work=HuffPost|access-date=November 12, 2017|dead-url=}}</ref> and exploitation of coffee farmers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/8355026|title=Storm in a coffee cup: Starbucks vs Ethiopia.|date=November 30, 2006|work=The Economist|access-date=April 23, 2018|dead-url=}}</ref>
In 2002, Starbucks branches throughout New York City issued a document to its workers entitled "What Should I do If Reverend Billy Is in My Store?",<ref name=talen>{{Cite web|url=http://thenewpress.com/books/what-should-i-do-if-reverend-billy-my-store|title=What Should I Do if Reverend Billy is in My Store|last=Talen|first=Bill|date=April 1, 2005|website=New York Press|dead-url=}}</ref> which outlines an evacuation protocol and a series of scripted reassurances that workers are ordered to deliver to disturbed or inquisitive customers. The title of the document is also the title of a book written by Talen, published by The New Press.<ref name=talen/>
In 2004, Starbucks persuaded a Los Angeles judge to issue an injunction against Talen, demanding that he cease and desist from "stalking, contacting, or sexually harassing the computerized cash registers of the Starbucks Company."<ref name=talen/>
===Golden Toads and Bank Actions=== In 2012 and 2013, Reverend Billy and the Church focused on the extinction of species brought by climate change, specifically targeting banks they said financed projects that worsened global warming. The symbolic centerpiece of these campaigns was the extinct [[Golden toad]], originally native to [[Monteverde Cloud Forest Reserve|Monteverde cloud forest]] in Costa Rica and a symbol for the crisis of [[Decline in amphibian populations|declining amphibian species]]. Savitri D and the choir wore papier mâché masks depicting golden toads as they entered JP Morgan Chase and HSBC banks.<ref name=vidal>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/nov/25/reverend-billy-jpmorgan-chase-toad-protest-talen|title=Reverend Billy faces year in prison for JP Morgan Chase toad protest|last=Vidal|first=John|date=November 25, 2013|work=The Guardian|access-date=April 23, 2018}}</ref>
In one action in a Chase bank in New York City, Reverend Billy and choir director Nehemiah Luckett were arrested and charged with riot, trespass, unlawful assembly, and disorderly conduct. According to the bank manager in a complaint to police, Reverend Billy and the choir were "running about the bank while wearing frog masks … jumping on to the bank's furniture, running about the bank, and screaming loudly at others for a number of minutes." The manager also stated that he thought the bank was being robbed, that he feared for his safety, and that customers or bank employees even cried.<ref name=vidal/>
Despite the complaints against them and what the New York prosecutor called a "criminal stunt," demanding that Talen go to prison for a year, their charges were eventually dropped.<ref name=kolbert/>
===British Petroleum and Liberate Tate=== As part of the Church of Stop Shopping's efforts to urge art institutions to reject sponsorship from petroleum companies, they have protested at a number of museums around the world.<ref name=vidaltate>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/blog/2011/jul/19/reverend-billy-tate-modern-bp|title=Reverend Billy leads exorcism of BP's 'evil spirit' from Tate Modern|last=Vidal|first=John|date=July 19, 2011|work=The Guardian|access-date=April 24, 2018}}</ref>
In July 2011, while on tour in the UK, Reverend Billy and the Choir staged an action at the Tate Modern in London to protest its sponsorship by the oil company British Petroleum (BP). The church was invited by a coalition of UK groups, including Liberate Tate, BP or Not BP, Platform, UK Tar Sands Network, London Rising Tide, Art Not Oil and Climate Rush.<ref name=vidaltate/>
While crowds observed the scene in the Turbine Room of the Tate, the choir splashed Reverend Billy and the BP sunflower logo with bottles of black oil.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=luoL5A-SHQk|title=Reverend Billy exorcizes BP at Tate Modern|last=Talen|first=Billy|date=July 19, 2011|via=YouTube|dead-url=|access-date=April 24, 2018}}</ref> After the performance, the protesters exited the museum singing onto the lawn outside, and rallied on the shore of the Thames against oil companies and their involvement in the arts.<ref name=vidaltate/>
===Robobees===
In 2014, Reverend Billy, Savitri D and the Choir turned their focus to [[colony collapse disorder]] affecting the world's honeybees. In one action, they entered the Micro-robotics Laboratory at Harvard's School of Engineering and Applied Science to confront scientists working on the invention of robot pollinators, popularly known as RoboBees. They purchased fruits and vegetables to place before a display case with a model of the RoboBee, singing and lamenting the focus of scientists replacing living bees with robots, rather than solving the collapse.<ref name=forde>{{Cite news|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2014/6/2/robotic-bee-project.html|title=Taking off from Harvard Yard: Flight of the RoboBees|last=Forde|first=Kaelyn|date=June 2, 2014|publisher=Al Jazeera|access-date=April 24, 2018}}</ref>
“We ask you to place your genius, your research, your scientific know-how into ''saving'' the honeybee," Talen said to those assembled. Attending the event and writing for [[The New Yorker]], [[Elizabeth Kolbert]] noted the confusion among some of the Harvard graduate students witnessing the singing and preaching. "We like people not to know if we're a political rally, a religious service, or a theatrical comedy about a church," Reverend Billy told Kolbert. "If they have all three spinning in their head, and they can't settle on one, then they're probably having a raw experience."<ref name=kolbert/>
===Monsanto=== The Church of Stop Shopping has also targeted chemical manufacturer [[Monsanto]] for its production of [[Glyphosate|glysophate]] herbicides and [[neonicotinoid]] pesticides.<ref name=forde/> In November 2014, the Church traveled to Monsanto's headquarters in [[St. Louis|St. Louis, Missouri]], where they held an "Organic Thanksgiving."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/events/1490386454559843/|title=Organic Thanksgiving at Monsanto World Headquarters|date=November 24, 2014|website=|dead-url=|access-date=April 24, 2018}}{{Primary source inline|date=May 2018}}</ref>
In 2015, Reverend Billy & The Stop Shopping Choir opened a series of shows for [[Neil Young]] during his tour in support of ''[[The Monsanto Years]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://diffuser.fm/fellow-monsanto-opponent-reverend-billy-to-open-for-neil-young-in-nyc/|title=Fellow Monsanto Opponent Reverend Billy to Open for Neil Young in NYC|last=Rossignol|first=Derrick|date=July 3, 2015|website=Diffuser|dead-url=|access-date=April 24, 2018}}</ref>
On October 13, 2016, Reverend Billy was arrested while protesting the [[World Food Prize]] in [[Des Moines, Iowa]]. He was charged with trespass for leaving the "free speech area" set up near the event.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://hyperallergic.com/342380/a-performance-troupe-takes-on-immigration-monsanto-and-standing-rock/|title=A Performance Troupe Takes on Immigration, Monsanto, and Standing Rock|last=Hamm|first=Theodore|date=December 2, 2016|work=Hyperallergenic|access-date=April 24, 2018}}</ref> The prosecutor for the state requested "that the Court preclude evidence or argument regarding 'free speech rights,' 'free expression,'right to assemble,' and/or other First Amendment arguments and evidence that 'free speech rights' can constitute 'justification' under the Iowa's criminal trespass statute, Iowa Code §716.7 (2015)."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://d3n8a8pro7vhmx.cloudfront.net/revbilly/pages/857/attachments/original/1483909235/Motion_in_Limine_-_Trepassing_Cases_(Talen___Cordaro)_(1).PDF?1483909235|title=STATE'S MOTION IN LIMINE, AND/OR FOR 5.104(A) RULING|date=January 2, 2017|website=|dead-url=|access-date=April 24, 2018}}</ref> The judge in the case ultimately dismissed the charges.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/2017/01/monsanto-amendment-170124075931929.html|title=On Monsanto and the First Amendment|last=Talen|first=Billy|date=January 24, 2017|publisher=Al Jazeera|access-date=April 24, 2018}}</ref>
In 2016, the Church released a guide called "The United States Map of Poisoned Parks and Playgrounds," which shows the dosage and location of glyphosate applications around the U.S.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.revbilly.com/nationalmap|title=U.S. Map of Poisoned Parks and Playgrounds|website=revbilly.com|dead-url=|access-date=April 24, 2018}}</ref>

Productions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.playloud.org/archiveandstore/en/dvd/60-reverend-billy.html|title=Reverend Billy & The Church of Stop Shopping|last=Post|first=Dietmar|last2=Palacios|first2=Lucía|year=2002|website=Play Loud!|dead-url=|access-date=April 30, 2018}}</ref> * ''Preacher with an Unknown God'', 2005 documentary by [[Rob VanAlkemade]], Honorable Mention in Short Filmmaking<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.sundance.org/pdf/press-releases/2006_SundanceFilmFestivalAwardWinners.pdf |title=2006 Sundance Film Festival Announces Awards for Documentary and Dramatic Films in Independent Film and World Cinema Competitions}}</ref> at the [[Sundance Film Festival]] * ''The Last Televangelist'', series on [[Free Speech TV]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/the-last-televangelist-reverend-billy-and-the-church-of-stop-shopping/564102/|title=The Last Televangelist: Reverend Billy and the Church of Stop Shopping|year=2013|website=TV Guide|dead-url=|access-date=April 30, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/cabaret/article/Reverend-Billy-The-Stop-Shopping-Choir-to-Bring-THE-HONEYBEELUJAH-SHOW-to-Joes-Pub-54-622-20140227|title=Reverend Billy & The Stop Shopping Choir to Bring THE HONEYBEELUJAH SHOW to Joe's Pub, 5/4-6/22|last=BWW News Desk|date=February 27, 2014|website=Broadway World|dead-url=|access-date=April 30, 2018}}</ref> * ''[[What Would Jesus Buy?]]'', 2007 feature-length documentary by [[Rob VanAlkemade]]. {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Use British English|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Richard Corney Grain | image = Corney-grain-obit.jpg | alt = | caption = Richard Corney Grain, 1880s | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1844|10|26|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Teversham]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1895|03|16|1844|10|26|df=yes}} | death_place = London | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = entertainer, songwriter | known_for = }} '''Richard Corney Grain''' (26 October 1844 – 16 March 1895), known by his stage name '''Corney Grain''', was an entertainer and songwriter of the late [[Victorian era]].
==Biography== [[Image:Corney Grain and Alfred Reed.png|thumb|160px|left|Corney Grain (left) and Alfred German Reed (right) portrayed in ''[[Entr'acte]]'' in 1895, the year they both died]] Born at [[Teversham]] in [[Cambridgeshire]], Grain was the youngest son of John Grain, a farmer, and his wife, Mary Anne. His sister, Harriet Ann, was the mother of the [[Barristers in England and Wales|barrister]] and judge Sir [[Travers Humphreys]]. Grain received what he referred to as "an average middle-class education". In 1858, at the age of 14, he attended school in [[Germany]].<ref name=grain>Corney Grain, Richard. ''Corney Grain, by Himself'', John Murray, London. (1888)</ref> Returning to [[United Kingdom|Britain]] with an interest in the [[Law]], he enrolled as a student of the [[Inner Temple]] on 27 April 1863, and was called to the [[Barrister|Bar]] on 30 April 1866.<ref>Foster, J. ''Men-at-the-bar: a biographical hand-list of the members of the various inns of court'', 2nd edn (1885)</ref> For a while he practised law on the Western Circuit. However, he had theatrical leanings, and sang and acted in private.
===Career=== Deciding to give up a legal career and try his hand on the stage,<ref>Brown, James D. ''British Musical Biography'', Read Books (2007), p. 170 {{ISBN|1-4067-5614-8}}</ref> on 16 May 1870 Grain joined what was known as the [[German Reed Entertainments]], at the [[Gallery of Illustration]], appearing in a sketch of his own called ''The School-Feast''.<ref name=watson>Watson, M. "Alfred German Reed and Corney Grain", ''The Theatre'', 4th series, No. 25 (1895), 221–23</ref> At the same time, Grain entertained privately, performing his comic musical sketches at the piano for fashionable parties and other venues.<ref name=watson/>
Grain remained with the [[Thomas German Reed|German Reed]]s until the end of his life and, after the death of another German Reed stalwart, [[John Orlando Parry]], Grain became the company's principal comedian and sketch artist. He moved with the company to [[St. George's Hall (London)|St George's Hall]], toured with it in the provinces, and in 1877, after the retirement of [[Priscilla Horton|Priscilla German Reed]], became the partner of the German Reeds' son, Alfred German Reed (1847-1895), who shared the management of the company with his mother from 1871.<ref>{{cite DNBSupp|wstitle=Reed, Thomas German|first=John Joseph |last=Knight}}</ref> Over twenty-five years, Grain wrote between fifty and sixty entertainments for the company, consisting of social sketches and songs with piano accompaniment. His songs included "The Masher King of Piccadilly" and "The Four-Horse Sharrybang". His private performances of comic sketches also remained fashionable throughout his career. His last sketch was ''Music à la mode''.<ref name=watson/> [[Image:corney-grain.jpg|thumb|right|160px|Richard Corney Grain as depicted by [[Leslie Ward|'Spy']] in ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine, historical)|Vanity Fair]]'' in 1885]] Grain was a large man with exceptionally large and expressive hands. On occasion he took part in comediettas or other dramatic performances, but he claimed that he did not enjoy acting and was not very good at it.<ref name=grain/> [[W. S. Gilbert]] disagreed, asking him to perform in his absurdist comedy with the German Reeds, ''[[Happy Arcadia]]'', as "the handsomest man in the world", because of Grain's comical appearance. Similarly in Gilbert's ''[[A Sensation Novel]]'', he played the "spirit of romance".<ref>Walters, p. 16</ref> He also played in Gilbert's ''[[Our Island Home]]'', ''[[Ages Ago]]'' and ''[[Eyes and No Eyes]]'' (amusingly, as [[Pierrot]]). Grain was a great friend and rival of [[Gilbert and Sullivan]] performer and fellow sketch-artist, [[George Grossmith]].
His [[autobiography]], ''Corney Grain, by Himself'', first appeared in ''[[Murray's Magazine]]'' and was later issued as a book in 1888. He died of "epidemic influenza" on 16 March 1895, at his home in Marylebone, London. His death, six days after that of Alfred German Reed, ended the [[German Reed Entertainments]], which had been popular for forty years.<ref name=Lloyd>[http://www.arthurlloyd.co.uk/StGeorgesHallLanghamPlaceLondon.htm "St George's Hall, Langham Place, Regent Street, London"], at the ArthurLloyd theatres website</ref>

Innes}} * Walters, Michael "A Brief Overview of the Life of Rutland Barrington" in ''The Gilbert & Sullivan News'', vol. II, no. 13, pp. 16–21 (Autumn/Winter 1998; The Gilbert and Sullivan Society).

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Use British English|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox orchestra | name = Royal Scottish National Orchestra (RSNO) | image = The_Royal_Scottish_National_Orchestra_Logo.jpg | caption = Official Royal Scottish National Orchestra logo | founded = 1891 | former_name = Scottish Orchestra
Scottish National Orchestra
Royal Scottish Orchestra | location = [[Glasgow]], [[Scotland]] | rehearsal_venue = RSNO_Centre | principal_conductor = [[Peter Oundjian]] | website = {{URL|www.rsno.org.uk}} }} The '''Royal Scottish National Orchestra''' (RSNO) is a Scottish orchestra, administratively based in [[Glasgow]] at the RSNO Centre. The RSNO receives support from the [[Scottish Government]].{{cite press release | url=http://www.scotland.gov.uk/News/Releases/2007/03/29094643 | title=National performing companies get official status | publisher=Scottish Government | date=29 April 2007 | accessdate=2008-08-21}} The RSNO performs throughout Scotland, at such venues as [[Glasgow Royal Concert Hall]], [[Usher Hall]] ([[Edinburgh]]), [[Caird Hall]] ([[Dundee]]), [[Aberdeen Music Hall]], [[Perth Concert Hall (Scotland)|Perth Concert Hall]] or [[Eden Court Theatre|Eden Court Inverness]]. The current chief executive director of the RSNO is Krishna Thiagarajan. [[Thomas Søndergård]] is the orchestra's current music director, since 2018. ==History== The precursor ensemble to the RSNO was established in 1843 to accompany the Glasgow Choral Union (today known as the RSNO Chorus). In 1891, the orchestra was recognised formally as the ''Scottish Orchestra'', with [[George Henschel]] as the ensemble's first principal conductor under that name. In 1950, the orchestra took the name of the ''Scottish National Orchestra''. The orchestra received [[patronage|royal patronage]] in 1977. It continued to use the name 'Scottish National Orchestra' until 1991, when it briefly used the title ''Royal Scottish Orchestra'', before changing to its present name. The orchestra's longest-serving principal conductor was Sir [[Alexander Gibson (conductor)|Alexander Gibson]], its first native Scottish principal conductor, from 1959 to 1984. During Gibson's tenure, beginning in 1979, the RSNO's base was at [[Henry Wood Hall, Glasgow|Henry Wood Hall]] in Glasgow and this space was also used as its recording venue. Gibson was particularly noted for his interpretations of [[Scandinavia]]n composers, notably [[Jean Sibelius]] and [[Carl Nielsen]]. His successor, [[Neeme Järvi]], continued this tradition, and also led the orchestra through its first complete [[Gustav Mahler]] cycle. Principal conductor from 1984 to 1988, Järvi currently has the title of conductor laureate with the RSNO. [[Bryden Thomson]], the orchestra's second Scottish principal conductor, maintained the [[Nordic countries|Nordic]] link with a cycle of Nielsen symphonies. [[Alexander Lazarev]] was principal conductor of the RSNO from 1997 to 2005, and now has the title of conductor emertius with the orchestra. [[Marin Alsop]] was the RSNO's principal guest conductor from 2000 to 2003, the first woman to hold the title. Garry Walker succeeded Alsop as principal guest conductor, serving from 2003 to 2007. [[Stéphane Denève]] was music director of the RSNO from 2005 to 2012.{{cite news | url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/home-news/national-orchestra-maestro-to-leave-scotland-1.1010874 | title=National orchestra maestro to leave Scotland | publisher=The Herald | author=Phil Miller | date=4 March 2010 | accessdate=2010-03-06}} During his tenure, the RSNO recorded music of Debussy and of [[Albert Roussel]], the latter for Naxos. In January 2011, the RSNO announced the appointment of [[Peter Oundjian]] as its next music director, as of the 2012–2013 season, with an initial contract of 4 years.{{cite press release | url=http://www.rsno.org.uk/index.php?option=com_myblog&show=638:oundjian-succeeds-stephane-deneve-in-2012-at-the-helm-of-scotlands-national-orchestra-.html&Itemid=81 | title=Peter Oundjian to be RSNO’s new Music Director | publisher=Royal Scottish National Orchestra | date=31 January 2011 | accessdate=2011-02-01}}{{cite news | url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/home-news/leading-violinist-gets-top-role-at-rsno-1.1082938 | title=Leading violinist gets top role at RSNO | publisher=The Herald | author=Phil Miller | date=1 February 2011 | accessdate=2011-02-01}} In October 2011, [[Thomas Søndergård]] was named the orchestra's principal guest conductor, as of the 2012–2013 season, with an initial contract of 3 years for 3 programmes per year.{{cite press release | url=http://www.rsno.org.uk/index.php?option=com_myblog&show=697:thomas-sondergard-joins-rsno-artistic-team.html&Itemid=81 | title=Thomas Søndergård joins RSNO Artistic Team | publisher=Royal Scottish National Orchestra | date=18 October 2011 | accessdate=2011-11-06}} In 2015, the orchestra took up new residence at the RSNO Centre and Glasgow Royal Concert Hall. The RSNO's current assistant conductor is Holly Mathieson, since September 2016. Oundjian is scheduled to conclude his tenure as RSNO music director after the close of the 2017-2018 season. In May 2017, the RSNO announced the appointment of Søndergård as its next principal conductor, effective with the 2018-2019 season.{{cite news | url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/arts_ents/music/15310504.RSNO_names_its_new_Music_Director/ | title=RSNO names its new Music Director | publisher=The Herald | author=Keith Bruce | date=2017-05-25 | accessdate=2017-05-26}} In June 2017, the RSNO appointed [[Elim Chan]] as its next principal guest conductor, effective 2018,{{cite press release | url=http://www.rsno.org.uk/rsno-principal-guest-conductor-appointment/ | title=RSNO Principal Guest Conductor appointment | publisher=Royal Scottish National Orchestra | date=20 June 2017 | accessdate=2017-07-06}} following her first guest-conducting appearance with the RSNO in January 2017 and a return engagement a fortnight later as an emergency substitute for [[Neeme Järvi]].{{cite news | url=http://www.scotsman.com/lifestyle/culture/music/music-review-the-rsno-elim-chan-1-4372553 | title=Music review: The RSNO & Elim Chan | work=The Scotsman | author=Susan Nickalls | date=2017-02-21 | accessdate=2017-07-06}} ==RSNO Chorus and RSNO Junior Chorus== The affiliated choruses of the RSNO are the [[Royal Scottish National Orchestra Chorus|RSNO Chorus]] and the RSNO Junior Chorus. The RSNO Chorus evolved from a choir formed in 1843 to sing the first full performance of Handel's ''Messiah'' in Scotland, in April 1844. In addition to its commitment to the RSNO, the Chorus performs independently and has toured worldwide. The current chorus director is [[Gregory Batsleer]]. In 1978, Jean Kidd formed the RSNO Junior Chorus. Since 1994, its director has been Christopher Bell. The RSNO Junior Chorus has a membership of around 400 singers, aged from eight to eighteen. The members learn to sing using the [[Zoltán Kodály]] method of training. ==Recordings== The orchestra has had a long-standing recording contract with [[Chandos Records]], particularly in the 1980s and 1990s. The RSNO has also recorded for [[Naxos Records]], most notably in a cycle of [[Anton Bruckner]] symphonies with the [[Georg Tintner]], cycles of [[Arnold Bax]] symphonies with [[David Lloyd-Jones (conductor)|David Lloyd-Jones]], and several recordings of American works (including the complete orchestral works of [[Samuel Barber]]) conducted by [[Marin Alsop]]. With Denève, their first Roussel recording{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2007/jun/08/classicalmusicandopera.shopping1 | title=Roussel: Bacchus et Ariane; Symphony No 3, RSNO/ Denève | publisher=The Guardian | author=Tim Ashley | date=8 June 2007 | accessdate=2010-03-06}} received the Diapason d'Or de l'année for Symphonic Music. The second disc in the series was released in 2008.{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/jun/13/classicalmusicandopera3 | title=Roussel: Symphony No 2; Suite in F; Pour une Fête de Printemps, RSNO/ Denève | publisher=The Guardian | author=Tim Ashley | date=13 June 2008 | accessdate=2010-02-20}} ==Principal Conductors== {| |valign="top"| * [[George Henschel]] (1893–1895) * [[Willem Kes]] (1895–1898) * Wilhelm Bruch (1898–1900) * [[Frederic Cowen]] (1900–1910) * [[Emil Młynarski]] (1910–1916) * [[Landon Ronald]] (1919–1923) * [[Václav Talich]] (1926–1927) |valign="top"| * [[Vladimir Golschmann]] (1928–1930) * [[John Barbirolli]] (1933–1936) * [[George Szell]] (1937–1939) * [[Warwick Braithwaite]] (1940–1946) * [[Walter Susskind]] (1946–1952) * [[Karl Rankl]] (1952–1957) * [[Hans Swarowsky]] (1957–1959) |valign="top"| * [[Alexander Gibson (conductor)|Alexander Gibson]] (1959–1984) * [[Neeme Järvi]] (1984–1988) * [[Bryden Thomson]] (1988–1990) * [[Walter Weller]] (1992–1997) * [[Alexander Lazarev]] (1997–2005) * [[Stéphane Denève]] (2005–2012) * [[Peter Oundjian]] (2012–2018) |valign="top"| * [[Thomas Søndergård]] (2018-present) |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Sources== * Playing for Scotland:History of the Royal Scottish Orchestra; author Conrad Wilson, published by Collins, 1993. ==External links== * [http://www.rsno.org.uk Royal Scottish National Orchestra official website] {{RSNO principal conductors}} {{National performing arts companies of Scotland}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:1891 establishments in Scotland]] [[Category:Musical groups established in 1891]] [[Category:Culture in Aberdeen]] [[Category:Culture in Dundee]] [[Category:Culture in Edinburgh]] [[Category:Music in Glasgow]] [[Category:Organisations based in Glasgow]] [[Category:Organisations based in Glasgow with royal patronage|National Orchestra]] [[Category:Scottish orchestras]] [[Category:National performing arts companies of Scotland]] [[Category:National orchestras|Scottish]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1891]]

{{Infobox software | name = SaferVPN | logo = SaferVPN-Logo150x150.jpg | logo size = 150px | released = March 2013 | developer = Safer Social Ltd.<ref name = PCWorld>{{cite web | url = https://www.pcworld.com/article/3200671/privacy/safervpn-vpn-review.html | publisher = PCWorld | title = SaferVPN: This newcomer is off to a good start | accessdate = 15 January 2018}}</ref> | latest release version = 4.9 | latest release date = {{Start date and age|2017|12|01|df=yes}} | operating system = [[Windows]], [[macOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[iOS]], [[Windows Phone]], Linux, Google Chrome extension, [[Mozilla]] add on | genre = [[Virtual private network|VPN]]<ref name = entrepreneur2>{{cite web | url = https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/306294| publisher = Entrepreneur | title = Protect Your Business! The 7 Cybersecurity Tools You Need as an Entrepreneur. | accessdate = 15 January 2018}}</ref> | license = Commercial | status = active | platform = Personal computer | size = 9.7MB | alexa = {{increase}}[https://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/safervpn.com 33,096] {{small|{{nowrap|(Global, {{as of|2018|04|01|alt=April 2018}})}}}} | language = [[English language|English]], [[German language|German]], [[French language|French]], [[Russian language|Russian]], [[Arabic language|Arabic]], [[Persian language|Persian]], [[Vietnamese language|Vietnamese]], [[Chinese language|Chinese]], [[Japanese language|Japanese]], [[Korean language|Korean]], [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]] and [[Turkish language|Turkish]] | website = {{URL|safervpn.com}} }} '''SaferVPN''' is a [[Virtual private network|Virtual Private Network]] utility developed by Safer Social, Ltd.<ref name = PCWorld/><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/yoavvilner/2015/12/15/these-are-the-16-israeli-startups-ready-to-take-on-2016/2/#508b7529475e|title=16 Israeli Startups Ready To Take On 2016|last=Vilner|first=Yoav|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-10-04|language=en}}</ref> The network protects user data from Wi-Fi security risks through end-to-end [[encryption]] of user connections.<ref name = entrepreneur2/> SaferVPN has provided free accounts to dissidents in Turkey, Iran, and Bangladesh.<ref name = huffingtonpost2>{{cite web | url = https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/iran-tightens-its-grasp-on-telegram-use_us_593ad6e6e4b014ae8c69dfe8 | title = Iran Tightens Its Grasp on Telegram Use| publisher = Huffington Post | accessdate = 24 January 2018}}</ref>
==History==
SaferVPN was released in 2013 by cybersecurity software developers, including founders Amit Bareket and Sagi Gidali. SaferVPN’s parent company began raising capital after creating and patenting a system created to aid law enforcement in identifying and catching car thieves.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/294754|title=How to Choose a VPN Provider for Your Business|last=Onibalusi| first=Segun| date=2017-07-21 | work=Entrepreneur| access-date=2017-10-04| language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://tech.eu/brief/safervpn-funding/|title=Israeli VPN startup SaferVPN raises $1 million for business services|work=Tech.eu|access-date=2017-10-04|language=en-US}}</ref> In the [[Imagine Cup|Microsoft Imagine Cup]] competition the first application cofounders Amit Bareket and Sagi Gidali assembled together made second place.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://techcompanynews.com/safervpn-raises-1m-venture-funding-provide-businesses-scalable-cloud-based-vpn-applications-customizable-cloud-management-portal/|title=SaferVPN Raises $1M Venture Funding To Provide Businesses With Scalable, Cloud-Based VPN Applications And A Customizable Cloud Management Portal - Tech Company News|date=2017-09-22|work=Tech Company News|access-date=2017-10-04|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== #UnblockTheWeb === In March 2014 when [[Turkey]] attempted to block [[Twitter]], SaferVPN launched the #UnblockTheWeb initiative to give individuals blocked by government censorship free access to a VPN.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2015/may/08/tech-industry-democracy-free-speech-rights-google-politics|title=Why Google and other tech giants are creating tools for political dissidents|last=Liacas|first=Tom|date=2015-05-08|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-10-04|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> In August, 2016, Unblock the Web provided a free VPN account to a coalition of Bangladeshi bloggers allowing them to communicate.<ref name = huffingtonpost3>{{cite web | url = https://www.huffingtonpost.com/karen-mesoznik/blogging-for-a-change-a-b_b_10161490.html | title = Blogging for a Change: A Blogger’s Journey to Advocate for His People and His Culture Through Blogging Activism| publisher = Huffington Post | accessdate = 24 January 2018}}</ref> In 2016, Apple approved SaferVPN to implement automatic Wi-Fi Security. Its patented technology alerts users when they connect to an unsecured Wi-Fi network even if their device is locked, preventing harmful data leaks.<ref name = geektime/>
==Technology== SaferVPN uses [[Protocols (computing)|protocols]] to secure data that is transmitted over its network. Each protocol varies in how the data is secured.<ref name = geektime>{{Cite news|url=https://www.geektime.com/2016/09/09/israeli-safervpn-launches-automatic-wi-fi-solution-to-keep-users-secure-on-the-go/|title=SaferVPN's launches Automatic Wi-Fi solution for mobile|date=2016-09-09|work=Geektime|access-date=2017-10-04|language=en-US}}</ref> SaferVPN’s supported protocols include: * [[OpenVPN]], the commonly used protocol due to its performance and security level. * Point-To-Point Tunneling Protocol ([[PPTP]]), a commonly used VPN protocol that uses basic encryption giving users fast connection speeds. * Layer 2 Tunneling Protocol ([[L2TP]]/IPSec), secure but slower than other protocols. L2TP is a good option if OpenVPN or IKEv2 aren’t available. Unlike PPTP, L2TP/IPSec requires a [[Symmetric-key algorithm|shared key]] or the use of certificates. * [[Internet Key Exchange|IKEv2]], the newest protocol available. Fastest of all protocols, it is secure and stable but not supported on all platforms.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://itspmagazine.com/from-the-newsroom/seriously-can-you-not-do-that-chapter-iv-insecure-use-of-public-wi-fi|title=Seriously?! Can You Not Do That? Chapter IV - Insecure Use of Public Wi-Fi|work=ITSPmagazine {{!}} Cybersecurity & Infosec News|access-date=2017-10-04|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/why-we-all-need-wi-fi-security_us_57d152e8e4b0eb9a57b7a093|title=Why We All Need Wi-Fi Security|last=Movements.org|date=2016-09-08|website=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=2017-10-04}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.networkworld.com/article/3186492/security/safervpn-says-it-takes-the-risk-out-of-using-public-wi-fi-connections.html|title=SaferVPN says it takes the risk out of using public Wi-Fi connections |last= Musthaler |first= Linda| work=Network World | access-date=2017-10-04|language=en}}</ref>
== Mission Statement == [[World Wide Web|The World Wide Web]] started to function as a "[[Global village|Global Village]]" without any meaning to geographical boundaries. It was accessible, open and equal to all users. Over the years, more and more regulations have been enforced on the users and the Internet has turned into a completely different ecosystem. Many countries have begun censoring a variety of sites and services (a prominent example is Iran and China, which blocked [[Facebook]], [[Google]], [[Gmail]], [[YouTube]] and many other well-known services).
In addition, a high percentage of content services are currently accessible only from parent countries. For example, [[Netflix]], the popular content service, blocks access to most content for those outside the US. [[Pandora Radio|Pandora]], [[Spotify]], and many other sites are also blocked.
In fact, the Internet has become a place with many "local villages" and defined boundaries.
SaferVPN focuses on developing a secure VPN service, which allows users to bypass censorship restrictions in more than 65 countries and bypass geographical limitations of various network services. In addition, the service enables users to enjoy network privacy and to avoid being monitored by governments and large companies and enjoy security over public wireless networks.
== See also == * [[Comparison of virtual private network services]]
== References == {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
{{Internet censorship circumvention technologies}}
