revision.comment: /* Structure */ Tidy up, disambiguate, link, correct, and footnote the section. Add orchestration notes.
revision.text:
:''This article is about the composition by Benjamin Britten. "Spring Symphony" is also the nickname of [[Robert Schumann|Schumann]]'s [[Symphony No. 1 (Schumann)|Symphony No. 1]]''
The '''Spring Symphony''' is [[Benjamin Britten]]'s [[opus number|Opus]] 44. It is dedicated to [[Serge Koussevitzky]] and the [[Boston Symphony Orchestra]]. It was premiered in the Concertgebouw, Amsterdam, on Thursday 14 July 1949 (not 9 July which is quoted by many sources) as part of the [[Holland Festival]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brittenpears.org/?page=britten/timelineLaunch.html |title=Britten timeline |publisher=brittenpears.org |date= |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref> when the composer was 35. At the premiere the tenor soloist was [[Peter Pears]], the soprano Jo Vincent and the contralto [[Kathleen Ferrier]]. The conductor was [[Eduard van Beinum]]. A recording of the performance survives and was first issued by Decca in August 1994.
In October 1950, Spring Symphony was performed at the [[Leeds Festival (classical music)|Leeds Triennial Musical Festival]] with a choir of 100 boys.<ref>{{cite web|title=Official Souvenir Programme: 1950 - Leeds Triennial Musical Festival|url=http://www.ebay.com.au/itm/1950-Kathleen-Ferrier-Arrau-Beecham-Baillie-De-Vito-Britten-Pears-Barbirolli-/161752247283?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_3&hash=item25a92f6bf3|publisher=(LTMF Committee) - City of Leeds UK 1950|accessdate=22 September 2015|quote=6 October 1950 - to be conducted by the composer (B. Britten) Halle Orchestra}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Leeds Classical Music|title=Discovering Leeds - (The Leeds) Triennial Music Festivals|url=http://www.leodis.net/discovery/discovery.asp?pageno=&page=20031110_356182278&topic=20031110_154781521&subsection=20031118_412594021|publisher=Leeds City Council UK - 2003|accessdate=21 September 2013|quote=...Spring Symphony performed October 6 1950 (at the LTMF)...}}</ref>
The Spring Symphony is a [[choral symphony]], written for [[soprano]], [[alto]] and [[tenor]] [[Solo (music)|solo]]ists, mixed [[choir|chorus]], boys' choir (often performed by a children's choir instead) and [[orchestra]]. Britten sets several poets' words, chiefly from the 16th and 17th century such as [[Edmund Spenser]], [[John Clare]] and [[George Peele]]. A notable exception is 'Out on the lawn I lie in bed' by his friend [[W. H. Auden]].
In the composer's own words, the work represents 'the progress of Winter to Spring and the reawakening of the earth and life which that means'.
== Structure == The Spring Symphony is made up of four parts, which correspond to the movements of a conventional symphony: ''[[Allegro (music)|Allegro]]'' with slow introduction, slow movement, ''[[scherzo]]'', and [[Finale (music)|finale]]. Part I begins with the dark and mysterious ''Shine Out'', a poem to the sun. Several more songs follow, including ''The Driving Boy'', which is a piece that features the boys' choir, at times whistling, and [[tambourine]]. The second part has several solos and quiet choruses and references to the month of May. The third part looks forward to May and then to summer. The Finale, ''London, to Thee I do Present'', comes to a climax when the entire chorus joins in a wordless, full-throated [[waltz]] representing the May revellers fortified by [[wine]] and [[ale]] (borne out by some rather unexpected [[modulation (music)|modulation]]s). The climax of the movement is the moment when the children’s voices, accompanied by [[unison]] [[French horn]]s, re-enter the scene and sing the 13th century [[Round (music)|round]] ''[[Sumer Is Icumen In|Sumer is icumen in]]''. The simple tune, sung in 2/4 time over the unyielding 3/4 waltz of the rest of the ensemble, finally achieves dominance. Eventually the celebrations subside, and the [[King of the May|Maylord]] then offers a final blessing with the proclamation: "And so, my friends, I cease."<ref name="score">{{cite book |last=Britten |first=Benjamin |date=1949 |title=Spring Symphony. Op. 44. For soprano, alto and tenor soli, mixed chorus, boys' choir and orchestra. Full score |url=http://www.boosey.com/shop/prod/Benjamin-Britten-Spring-Symphony-op-44-study-score-Study-Score-Hawkes-Pocket-Score-66/696677 |location=London |publisher=Hawkes & Son |asin=B0000CTOU1}}</ref>
The large orchestra includes triple [[Woodwind instrument|woodwinds]], two [[harp]]s, and a large [[Percussion instrument|percussion]] section. Each song has its distinctive scoring, ranging from just first and second [[violin]]s accompanying the tenor (''Waters Above!'') to full orchestra in the first and last songs. The last movement adds the call of a cow-horn, specifying a G, C, and F.<ref name="score"/>
== Songs in the Spring Symphony == The songs (and authors) in the Spring Symphony are as follows:
===Part 1=== *1. Introduction: ''Shine Out'' (Anonymous) (mixed chorus) *2. ''The Merry Cuckoo'' ([[Edmund Spenser]]) (tenor solo) *3. ''Spring, the Sweet Spring'' ([[Thomas Nashe]]) (soprano, alto and tenor soli, mixed chorus) *4. ''The Driving Boy'' ([[George Peele]], [[John Clare]]) (soprano solo and boys' choir) *5. ''The Morning Star'' ([[John Milton]]) (mixed chorus)
===Part 2=== *6. ''Welcome, Maids of Honour'' ([[Robert Herrick (poet)|Robert Herrick]]) (alto solo) *7. ''Waters Above!'' ([[Henry Vaughan]]) (tenor solo) *8. ''Out on the lawn I Lie in bed'' ([[W. H. Auden]]) (alto solo and mixed chorus)
===Part 3=== *9. ''When will my May Come?'' ([[Richard Barnfield]]) (tenor solo) *10. ''Fair and Fair'' ([[George Peele]]) (soprano and tenor soli) *11. ''Sound the Flute!'' ([[William Blake]]) (male chorus, female chorus and boys' choir)
===Part 4=== *12. Finale: ''London, to Thee I do Present'' (Anon, closing words from ''[[The Knight of the Burning Pestle]]'' by [[Francis Beaumont]]) (soprano, alto and tenor soli, mixed chorus and boys' choir)
==See also== *[[List of symphonies by name]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Benjamin Britten|state=collapsed}}
[[Category:Compositions by Benjamin Britten]] [[Category:20th-century symphonies|Britten Spring]] [[Category:Choral symphonies|Spring Symphony]] [[Category:1949 compositions]]

'''Talawa Theatre Company''' is a [[Black British]] [[theatre company]] founded in 1986.<ref name=V&A>[http://www.vam.ac.uk/content/articles/b/history-of-black-and-asian-performance-in-britain/ "Black & Asian Performance in Britain 1970 onwards - Talawa Theatre Company"]. V&A.</ref><ref name=Archives>[http://www.vam.ac.uk/vastatic/theatre/archives/ttcf.html "Records of Talawa Theatre Company, 1962-2007"], [[Victoria and Albert Museum]]: Theatre Collections.</ref> The core of the company's work is championing reinterpretations of classic plays, developing new writing and directing talent and producing plays from and about the [[African diaspora]] and Black British Community.<ref name=Archives /><ref>Helen Kolawole, [https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2003/jul/26/whoswhoinbritishtheatre.features "Look who's taking the stage"], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 26 July 2003.</ref><ref name=MovingHere>[http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20131205021331/http://www.movinghere.org.uk/galleries/histories/caribbean/culture/theatre4.htm "New Black theatre companies"], Moving Here – Migration histories.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.talawa.com/|title=Homepage|publisher=}}</ref> The Company is a National Portfolio Organisation, supported by funding from [[Arts Council England]] in recognition of consistently high quality artistic work and audience development,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theaudienceagency.org/blog/case-study-talawa|title=Case Study - Talawa Theatre Company|website=The Audience Agency}}</ref> with an uplift in its grant for the period between 2018 - 2022.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artscouncil.org.uk/blog/museums-libraries-artforms-and-national-portfolio |title=Museums, libraries, artforms and the National Portfolio | Arts Council England |publisher=Artscouncil.org.uk |date=2017-07-03 |accessdate=2018-09-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/opinion/2017/the-editors-view-no-alarms-and-no-surprises-in-npo-funding/|title=The Editor's View: No alarms and no surprises in NPO funding - Opinion - The Stage|date=27 June 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
Since 2011 Talawa Theatre Company has been led by artistic director [[Michael Buffong]], whose career spans theatre, TV and film.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/features/interviews/2016/michael-buffong-putting-black-actors-stage-easy-bit/|title=Michael Buffong: ‘Putting black actors on stage is the easy bit’ - Interviews - The Stage|date=28 March 2016|publisher=}}</ref><ref>Natalie Woolman, [http://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2011/10/michael-buffong-appointed-talawa-artistic-director/ "Michael Buffong appointed Talawa artistic director"], ''[[The Stage]]'', 13 October 2011.</ref><ref name=Gardner>[[Lyn Gardner]], [https://www.theguardian.com/stage/theatreblog/2015/jun/09/do-we-need-diversity-quotas-for-theatre "Do we need diversity quotas for theatre?"], ''The Guardian'', 9 June 2015.</ref><ref name=Snow>Georgia Snow, [https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2015/michael-buffong-use-diversity-quotas-nothing-will-change/ "Michael Buffong: ‘Use diversity quotas or nothing will change’"], ''The Stage'', 5 June 2015.</ref><ref name=Snow /><ref name=BuffongProfile>[http://www.artsindustry.co.uk/features/bringing-black-into-the-theatre-mainstream/225 "Bringing Black into the Theatre Mainstream"] (Michael Buffong profile), ''Arts Industry (AI)'', 16 December 2012.</ref>
The name Talawa comes from [[Jamaican patois]] saying "''me lickle but me talawa''",<ref>[http://www.talawa.com/about/our-story/ "Our Story"], Talawa website.</ref> meaning "''small but feisty''".<ref name=MovingHere /><ref name=Obano>Nisha Obano, [http://www.encyclopediaofafroeuropeanstudies.eu/encyclopedia/talawa-theatre-company/ "Talawa Theatre Company"]. ''Encyclopedia of AfroEuropean Studies''.</ref>
==Mission== The company's mission is to provide opportunities for black directors, writers and actors, to use black culture to enrich British theatre, and to enlarge theatre audiences seeing black work.<ref name=V&A /> Talawa's work embraces touring classic work on the mid-scale to regional theatres in the [[UK]], literary and participation activities, finding and developing new writers and scripts, and developing theatre-makers and directors, alongside workshops for schools, colleges and corporate clients and presenting new work by emerging artists.<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref name=AboutTalawa>[http://www.talawa.com/about/talawas-mission/ "Talawa's Mission"], Talawa Theatre website.</ref>
==History== Jamaican-born [[Yvonne Brewster]], [[Mona Hammond]], [[Carmen Munroe]] and Inigo Espejel founded the company in 1986.<ref name=V&A /><ref name=Standard>Nick Curtis, [https://www.standard.co.uk/goingout/theatre/michael-buffong-i-want-to-turn-talawa-into-the-goto-company-for-black-talent-8049923.html "Michael Buffong: ‘I want to turn Talawa into the go-to company for black talent’"], ''London Evening Standard'', 15 August 2012.</ref><ref name=Iqbal>Nosheen Iqbal, [https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2011/may/29/talawa-theatre-company-25th-anniversary "Talawa theatre company: the fights of our lives"], ''The Guardian'', 29 May 2011.</ref> Talawa's first production in 1986 was ''The Black Jacobins'' by [[C. L. R. James]], a play that had not been performed in England for 50 years, and never before with an all-black cast.<ref name=Archives />
Talawa has produced and toured classic work by numerous playwrights and writers including [[Dennis Scott (writer)|Dennis Scott]], [[Derek Walcott]], [[Galt McDermot]], [[Wole Soyinka]], [[James Baldwin]], [[Michael Abbensetts]], [[Trevor Rhone]], [[William Shakespeare]], [[Oscar Wilde]], [[Samuel Beckett]], [[Tariq Ali]] and [[Arthur Miller]] and worked with a variety of directors and actors including [[Michaela Coel]], [[Cathy Tyson]], [[Dona Croll]], [[Ray Shell]], [[Norman Beaton]], [[Horace Ove]], [[Paulette Randall]], [[Don Warrington]], [[Fraser Ayres]] and [[David Harewood]]. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.talawa.com/articles/30-years-of-achievement/ |title=30 years of achievement |publisher=Talawa |date=2018-05-16 |accessdate=2018-09-01}}</ref><ref name=Archives /><ref>Tony Howard, [http://www.newstatesman.com/culture/2014/03/we-need-more-racial-diversity-stage-both-sides-pond "We need more racial diversity on the stage both sides of the pond"], ''[[New Statesman]]'', 25 March 2014.</ref>
Previous artistic directors have included [[Yvonne Brewster]], Ben Thomas, [[Paulette Randall]], [[Bonnie Greer]] and [[Patricia Cumper]].
==Today and Recent Productions== Talawa Theatre Company's artistic director is [[Michael Buffong]].<ref>Matthew Hemley, [https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2015/national-theatre-rsc-lead-example-appointing-bame-associates-says-verma/ "National Theatre and RSC should 'lead by example' by appointing more BAME associates, says Verma"], ''The Stage'', 22 April 2015.</ref><ref name=Thorpe>Vanessa Thorpe, [https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2015/oct/25/black-actors-lenny-henry-theatre "After a century of black British theatre, actors still struggle to take centre stage"] (on [[Lenny Henry]]'s [[BBC Radio 4]] series), ''The Observer'', 25 October 2015.</ref> Michael Buffong featured on Creative Review's '50 Creative Leaders' list in 2017,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.creativereview.co.uk/creativeleaders50/|title=Creative Leaders 50 - People driving change in the creative industries|website=www.creativereview.co.uk}}</ref> having also featured in the Powerlist, celebrating Britain's most influential people of African or African Caribbean heritage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.powerlist.co.uk/|title=Powerlist|website=www.powerlist.co.uk}}</ref>
Talawa Theatre Company produces a major touring production annually.<ref name=BuffongProfile />
==Artist Development== As well as touring major works across the UK, Talawa Theatre Company commissions new plays, develops artists and directors.
In '''January 2017''' Talawa announced the creation of MAKE, a career development community of Black theatre artists.<ref name="thestage.co.uk2">{{cite web|url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2017/talawa-launches-make-scheme-support-black-artists-theatre/|title=Talawa launches Make scheme to support black artists in theatre - News - The Stage|date=1 February 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/uk-regional/article/Talawa-Theatre-Creates-New-Industry-Pathway-For-Black-Artists-20170201|title=Talawa Theatre Creates New Industry Pathway For Black Artists|first=BWW News|last=Desk|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="talawa.com2">{{cite web|url=http://www.talawa.com/articles/make-a-brand-new-community-of-black-artists/|title=MAKE: a brand new community of Black artists|publisher=}}</ref> Called MAKE, the new career development community creates 250 new opportunities for Black artists every year, across four areas, enabling artists to make connections and build the support they need to create new work.<ref name="thestage.co.uk2"/><ref name="auto"/><ref name="talawa.com2"/> A Talawa spokesperson commented that ''"Diversity projects tend to be just that – projects – and as a quick-fix approach, they are not building an infrastructure. What we need is sustained engagement that provides artists with a pathway into the industry, and the footholds to keep them there ..."''.<ref name="thestage.co.uk2"/>
As part of MAKE, Talawa also offers a script reading service and produces an annual season of play readings, Talawa Firsts, which showcases the best new [[Black British|black]] writing talent. The Company also supports and develops emerging theatre-makers<ref name="ReferenceA"/> – performers, designers and technicians – through their flagship participation programmes TYPT, Studio Firsts and Talawa Firsts.<ref name=AboutTalawa /><ref name=Standard /><ref name=Iqbal /><ref>John Nassouri, [http://www.islingtongazette.co.uk/news/features_2_4368/islington_people_bbc_director_takes_reins_at_black_led_theatre_company_1_1419525 "Islington people: BBC director takes reins at Black-led theatre company"], ''[[Islington Gazette]]'', 24 June 2012.</ref>
==Moon On A Rainbow Shawl== The '''2013/14''' production was a revival of ''[[Moon on a Rainbow Shawl]]'' by [[Errol John]], directed by Michael Buffong and which toured across the UK, in addition to playing at the [[Royal National Theatre]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2013/talawas-michael-buffong-to-revive-moon-on-a-rainbow-shawl/|title=Talawa’s Michael Buffong to revive Moon on a Rainbow Shawl - News - The Stage|date=8 May 2013|publisher=}}</ref><ref>[http://www.nationaltheatre.org.uk/shows/moon-on-a-rainbow-shawl "Moon on a Rainbow Shawl by Errol John"], National Theatre.</ref><ref>[[Kate Kellaway]], [https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2012/mar/18/moon-rainbow-shawl-talk-about-shivered "Moon on a Rainbow Shawl; Can We Talk about This?; Shivered – review"], ''[[The Observer]]'', 18 March 2012.</ref> Critics described the show as ''"an absolute must-see"'' <ref>{{cite web|url=http://exeuntmagazine.com/reviews/moon-on-a-rainbow-shawl/|title=Moon on a Rainbow Shawl - Exeunt Magazine|website=exeuntmagazine.com}}</ref> ''"a well-crafted slow burner"''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/goingout/theatre/moon-on-a-rainbow-shawl-national-se1-review-7573175.html|title=Moon on a Rainbow Shawl, National, SE1 - review|publisher=}}</ref> and ''"treats the characters as real people rather than outrageous exotics ... Justice, you feel, has at last been done ..."''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2012/mar/15/moon-rainbow-shawl-review|title=Moon on a Rainbow Shawl – review|first=Michael|last=Billington|date=15 March 2012|website=the Guardian}}</ref>
==All My Sons== Talawa Theatre Company toured a revival of [[Arthur Miller]]'s ''[[All My Sons]]'' in '''Spring 2015'''.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-31363531 "All My Sons tour marks Arthur Miller centenary"], BBC News, 13 February 2015.</ref><ref name="thestage.co.uk"/><ref name="thestage.co.uk">Andrew Clarke, [https://www.thestage.co.uk/reviews/2015/sons/ "All My Sons review"], ''The Stage'', 18 February 2015.</ref><ref>Glen Pearce, [http://www.thepublicreviews.com/all-my-sons-new-wolsey-theatre-ipswich/ "All My Sons – New Wolsey Theatre, Ipswich"], ''The Public Reviews'', 17 February 2015.</ref><ref>Anne Morley-Priestman, [http://www.whatsonstage.com/ipswich-theatre/reviews/all-my-sons-talawa-tour_37186.html "All My Sons (Tour) - 'Michael Buffong ratchets up the tension'"], ''What's On Stage'', 18 February 2015.</ref>
Critics described the production as ''"heart wrenching"'' <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thereviewshub.com/all-my-sons-richmond-theatre-london/|title=All My Sons – Richmond Theatre, London|date=1 April 2015|publisher=}}</ref> and ''"Talawa’s contribution to the Arthur Miller centenary ... is a worthwhile one"'' <ref>{{cite web|url=https://theoxfordculturereview.com/2015/03/19/review-all-my-sons/|title=Review: All My Sons|date=19 March 2015|publisher=}}</ref> which ''"ratchets up the tension"'' <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/ipswich-theatre/reviews/all-my-sons-talawa-tour_37186.html|title=All My Sons (Tour) - 'Michael Buffong ratchets up the tension'|publisher=}}</ref>
==King Lear== In '''October 2015''', Talawa announced a new production of [[William Shakespeare]]'s ''[[King Lear]]'' starring [[Don Warrington]] in the title role.<ref name=Thorpe /><ref>[http://www.talawa.com/articles/dw-to-play-king-lear/ "Don Warrington to play King Lear"], Talawa.</ref><ref>David Hutchinson, [https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2015/don-warrington-cast-as-king-lear-at-the-royal-exchange/ "Don Warrington cast as King Lear at the Royal Exchange"], ''The Stage'', 12 October 2015.</ref> [[King Lear]] was co-produced with the [[Royal Exchange Theatre]] in Manchester.
Reviews singled out the production as being ''"as close to definitive as can be"'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2016/apr/07/king-lear-review-royal-exchange-manchester|title=King Lear review – as close to definitive as can be|first=Alfred|last=Hickling|date=7 April 2016|website=the Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.talawa.com/articles/king-lear-reviewed/|title=King Lear Reviewed|publisher=}}</ref> ''"a significant production"''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/theatre-king-lear-at-the-royal-exchange-manchester-6z7xh5r8d|title=Theatre: King Lear at the Royal Exchange, Manchester|first=Kate|last=Bassett|date=8 April 2016|publisher=|via=www.thetimes.co.uk}}</ref> and "outstanding".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/reviews/2016/king-lear-review-at-the-royal-exchange-theatre-manchester/|title=King Lear review at Royal Exchange Theatre, Manchester|publisher=}}</ref> [[Don Warrington]]'s performance as [[King Lear]] was described as ''"a heartbreaking tour de force"''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/theatre/what-to-see/don-warringtons-king-lear-is-a-heartbreaking-tour-de-force/|title=Don Warrington's King Lear is a heartbreaking tour de force|first=Claire|last=Allfree|date=18 May 2016|publisher=|via=www.telegraph.co.uk}}</ref>
In late '''June 2016''', Talawa Theatre Company announced the film of [[King Lear]], in a collaboration with the [[Royal Exchange Theatre]] and funded by the digital commissioning body The Space, the film was available to view on-demand and free of charge on [[BBC iPlayer]] and the [[British Council]]'s websites for three months in summer 2016, ahead of a cinema release in September and October 2016, and closed 2016 by being screened on BBC4 on Christmas Day.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thespace.org/artwork/talawa-king-lear|title=Get closer to King Lear|date=12 April 2016|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.royalexchange.co.uk/king-lear-the-film|title=King Lear: The Film - News - Royal Exchange Theatre|first=Eleanor|last=Higgins|website=www.royalexchange.co.uk}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.talawa.com/articles/king-lear-the-film/|title=King Lear: The Film|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b086kg3n|title=King Lear - BBC Four|website=BBC}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/schedules/p00fzl6b/2016/12/25|title=BBC Four - Schedules, Sunday 25 December 2016|website=BBC}}</ref>
==Girls== Also in '''2016''', Talawa also co-produced the award-winning play by Theresa Ikoko,<ref name="talawa.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.talawa.com/articles/reviews-for-girls/ |title=Reviews for Girls |publisher=Talawa.com |date=2018-05-16 |accessdate=2018-09-01}}</ref> '''''Girls''''', the story of three young women kidnapped by extremists.<ref name="talawa.com"/><ref name="thetimes.co.uk">{{cite web|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/theatre-hightide-festival-at-aldeburgh-suffolk-bxgtjktl7|title=Theatre: HighTide Festival at Aldeburgh, Suffolk|first=Sam|last=Marlowe|date=13 September 2016|publisher=|via=www.thetimes.co.uk}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vice.com/en_uk/article/girls-is-a-play-about-how-we-forget-the-victims-of-terrorism|title=How to Talk About Terrorism On Stage|date=5 October 2016|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thefword.org.uk/2016/09/theresa-ikoko-interview/|title=“I’m so bloody glad I get to call myself a woman” - The F-Word|website=www.thefword.org.uk}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/westend/article/BWW-Review-GIRLS-Soho-Theatre-1-October-2016-20161002|title=BWW Review: GIRLS, Soho Theatre, 1 October 2016|first=Aliya|last=Al-Hassan|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://theatrecat.com/2016/09/18/girls-hightide-festival-aldeburgh/|title=GIRLS Hightide Festival, Aldeburgh|date=18 September 2016|publisher=}}</ref>
The Times referred to Girls as ''“Scorchingly intelligent and as powerful as a gut punch”''<ref name="thetimes.co.uk"/> while Time Out called it ''" ... clever, audacious, entertaining and full of promise."'' <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeout.com/london/theatre/girls|title=Girls|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.talawa.com/articles/reviews-for-girls|title=Reviews for Girls|publisher=}}</ref>
Theresa Ikoko commented on her experience of working with Talawa to get the story produced, saying: ''"This isn’t the first play I’ve written, but it’s my first produced play. The first play I wrote, I didn’t really know it was a play, it was just for me. I would read it over the phone to my friend and when I’d finished he said I had to show it to someone. Talawa Theatre Company found me and [artistic director] Michael Buffong put that play in a Talawa Firsts show, and I got signed by my agent there ... Talawa completely took a chance on me. I had no training or experience or credentials, and there was no one to offer a reference. But Michael believed in me. It took me forever though, probably until the opening night of Girls at HighTide, for me to believe him."''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/features/interviews/2016/theresa-ikoko-putting-your-work-out-there-is-like-sending-your-child-to-school-naked/|title=Theresa Ikoko: 'Putting your work out there is like sending your child to school naked' - Interviews - The Stage|date=25 October 2016|publisher=}}</ref>
In '''2017''', Girls went on tour with a new cast, having first played at Edinburgh Festival where it was presented as part of the [[British Council]] Edinburgh Showcase.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.talawa.com/productions/girls-on-tour/|title=Girls on tour|publisher=}}</ref>
==Half Breed== Described variously as a story about growing up mixed-race, and as a story about friendship, Half Breed was written by Natasha Marshall and first performed at Talawa Firsts 2016 before being developed further by both Talawa and Soho Theatre.<ref name="talawa.com1">{{cite web|url=http://www.talawa.com/productions/half-breed-at-soho-theatre/|title=Half Breed at Soho Theatre|publisher=}}</ref> That same partnership presented Half Breed at Edinburgh in '''summer 2017'''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/1267048a-7db9-11e7-ab01-a13271d1ee9c|title=Subscribe to read|website=Financial Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2017/aug/13/edinburgh-fringe-theatre-whales-revlon-girl-venus-adonis-half-breed-review|title=Edinburgh theatre review – a world without borders, almost|first=Clare|last=Brennan|date=13 August 2017|website=the Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/edinburgh-theatre-half-breed-at-the-box-assembly-george-square-zx77wb2gt|title=Edinburgh theatre review: Half Breed at The Box, Assembly George Square|first=Ann|last=Treneman|date=17 August 2017|publisher=|via=www.thetimes.co.uk}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/goingout/theatre/half-breed-theatre-review-funny-gripping-show-packs-a-punch-a3610856.html|title=Half Breed, theatre review: Funny, gripping show packs a punch|publisher=}}</ref> At the time Marshall said ''"My whole lifeI’ve been holding my breath but when I perform Half-Breed I feel like I’m breathing. I want to bring something real and different to the Fringe. I want to create a conversation, I want to open people’s minds up.”'' <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.talawa.com/productions/half-breed-at-edinburgh|title=Half Breed at Edinburgh|publisher=}}</ref>
Half Breed was nominated as a 'Best New Play' at the UK Theatre Awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2017/women-dominate-best-new-play-category-uk-theatre-awards/|title=Women dominate best new play category at UK Theatre Awards|date=14 September 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="talawa.com1"/> Half Breed was also nominated for the 'Best New Play', 'Best Female Performance' and 'Most Promising New Playwright' awards in the Offies, an award presented by Off West End.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.offwestend.com/index.php/pages/the_offies |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-05-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715130741/http://www.offwestend.com/index.php/pages/the_offies |archivedate=2014-07-15 |df= }}</ref>
Half Breed had a sell-out London run following its success at Edinburgh.<ref name="talawa.com1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2017/oct/08/why-we-all-need-a-bolshie-friend-column-charlie-brinkhurst-cuff|title=Why we all need a bolshie friend - Charlie Brinkhurst-Cuff|first=Charlie|last=Brinkhurst-Cuff|date=8 October 2017|website=the Guardian}}</ref> The co-production of Half Breed also toured India in autumn 2017, where it was well received by audiences and critics alike. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thehindu.com/entertainment/theatre/natasha-marshalls/article19790740.ece|title=How dark are those racist jokes|first=Sravasti|last=Datta|date=3 October 2017|publisher=|via=www.thehindu.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/bengaluru/half-breed-speaks-about-racism-with-a-touch-of-humour/articleshow/60941204.cms|title=Half Breed speaks about racism with a touch of humour - Times of India|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://uk-india.britishcouncil.in/events/half-breed|title=Half Breed - British Council|website=uk-india.britishcouncil.in}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mid-day.com/articles/creators-of-a-poignant-play-tell-us-how-racism-still-lingers/18681187|title=Creators of a poignant play tell us how racism still lingers|date=26 October 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thehindu.com/entertainment/theatre/all-of-us-have-been-victims-and-perpetrators/article19956711.ece|title=‘All of us have been victims and perpetrators’|first=Vikram|last=Phukan|date=31 October 2017|publisher=|via=www.thehindu.com}}</ref>
Half Breed also toured the UK in Spring 2018 as a co-production between Talawa Theatre Company and [[Soho Theatre]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.talawa.com/productions/half-breed-uk-tour-2018/|title=Half Breed UK Tour 2018|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://sohotheatre.com/events/half-breed-uk-tour/|title=Half Breed UK Tour 2018 - Soho Theatre|publisher=}}</ref>
==Guys and Dolls== Talawa announced their '''winter 2017''' co-production with the [[Royal Exchange Theatre]] of the Damon Runyon inspired musical, [[Guys and Dolls]], the first in the UK with an all-Black cast.<ref name="thestage.co.uk1">{{cite web|url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2017/cast-announced-uks-first-black-guys-dolls/|title=Cast announced for UK's first all-black Guys and Dolls|date=18 October 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/westend/article/Casting-Revealed-For-UKs-First-All-Black-GUYS-AND-DOLLS-20171018|title=Casting Revealed For UK's First All-Black GUYS AND DOLLS|first=BWW News|last=Desk|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2017/jun/07/jubilee-manchester-royal-exchange-derek-jarman-toyah-willcox|title=Derek Jarman's punk classic Jubilee to be reignited on stage|first=Chris|last=Wiegand|date=7 June 2017|website=the Guardian}}</ref><ref name="thestage.co.uk1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/cast-announced-for-uks-first-all-black-production-of-guys-and-dolls|title=Cast Announced for U.K.’s First All-Black Production of Guys and Dolls - Playbill|website=Playbill}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/showbiz/harry-potter/news/a841013/harry-potter-actor-strictly-come-dancing-joins-first-all-black-cast-of-guys-and-dolls-theatre-uk/|title=Potter star joins first all-black Guys and Dolls cast|date=19 October 2017|publisher=}}</ref> Among the cast announced for Guys and Dolls were [[Ray Fearon]], Ashley Zhanghazha, Abiona Omonua, and Lucy Vandi.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2017/10/18/guys-and-dolls-announces-uks-first-ever-all-black-cast-7008875/|title=Guys and Dolls musical announces UK’s first ever all-black cast|date=18 October 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.talawa.com/productions/guys-dolls/|title=Guys and Dolls|publisher=}}</ref> [[Guys and Dolls]] played at Manchester's [[Royal Exchange Theatre]] in an extended run from December 2017 to February 2018.
Reviews had particular praise for the music, direction, relocation to Harlem and sense of spectacle: ''"the gamblers ... are a bunch of sharp-suited peacocks clad in rainbow hues."'' <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2017/dec/07/guys-and-dolls-review-royal-exchange-manchester|title=Guys and Dolls review – swaggering Harlem grit rocks the Broadway boat|first=Lyn|last=Gardner|date=7 December 2017|website=the Guardian}}</ref> ; ''"Whoever had the idea of moving this classic musical from one part of New York to another bit, just up the road, needs to be congratulated. This version of Frank Loesser’s musical, which swirls around the lives of the petty gangsters and their “dolls” who inhabit New York’s underbelly, moves the action to Harlem at its prewar height in 1939. It is a Talawa production with an all-black cast and it is terrific from the get-go."'' <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/theatre-review-guys-and-dolls-at-the-royal-exchange-theatre-manchester-3vl9kxlrz|title=Theatre review: Guys and Dolls at the Royal Exchange Theatre, Manchester|first=Ann|last=Treneman|date=8 December 2017|publisher=|via=www.thetimes.co.uk}}</ref> ; ''"Relocated to Harlem, this fine new production of Frank Loesser’s classic musical retains a threat of violence under a cartoon-bright exterior"''. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2017/dec/10/guys-and-dolls-review-colourful-characters-royal-exchange-manchester|title=Guys and Dolls review – larger than life, but with a core of grit|first=Clare|last=Brennan|date=10 December 2017|website=the Guardian}}</ref>
==Superhoe== In October 2018, Talawa and [[Royal Court Theatre]] announced their co-production of Superhoe by Nicole Lecky.<ref>https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2018/jack-thorne-john-tiffany-reunite-royal-court-theatres-new-sason/</ref><ref>https://royalcourttheatre.com/whats-on/superhoe/</ref><ref>http://www.talawa.com/productions/superhoe</ref>
==Awards== In '''autumn 2016''', the [[Arts Council England]] announced that it had awarded £478,671 to a partnership between Talawa Theatre Company and [[Birmingham Repertory Theatre]] to boost the visibility and profile of established and emerging Black and Minority Ethnic talent with a three month [[West End Theatre]] season with a wrap around festival of new work.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artscouncil.org.uk/news-and-jobs/%C2%A346-million-help-diversity-flourish|title=£4.6 million to help diversity flourish - Arts Council England|website=www.artscouncil.org.uk}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite web|url=http://www.talawa.com/articles/talawa-sustained/|title=Talawa Sustained|publisher=}}</ref>
A further award of more than £400,000 was awarded to a consortium, of which Talawa Theatre Company is a part, to support the development of established and emerging BAME theatre makers and to increase their representation across the wider theatre sector.<ref name="ReferenceB"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tiatafahodzi.com/blog/consortium-led-by-tiata-fahodzi-wins-ace-sustained-theatre-fund/ |title=Consortium led by tiata fahodzi wins ACE Sustained Theatre Fund |publisher=tiata fahodzi |date=2016-10-13 |accessdate=2018-09-01}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.talawa.com Talawa Theatre Company website.] * Nisha Obano, [http://www.encyclopediaofafroeuropeanstudies.eu/encyclopedia/talawa-theatre-company/ "Talawa Theatre Company"], in ''Encyclopedia of AfroEuropean Studies''. * [http://www.vam.ac.uk/vastatic/theatre/archives/ttcf.html "Records of Talawa Theatre Company, 1986-2007"]. revision.comment: /* History */clean up; http→https for [[The New York Times]]. using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=May 2011}}
The term '''telematic performance''' refers to a live performance (art, dance, music, etc.) which makes use of [[telecommunications]] and [[information technology]] to distribute the performers between two or more locations.
While this may involve use of conventional [[videoconferencing]] technology, it has more recently come to mean the use of internet technologies. Performance groups my also refer to their events as ''internet concerts'', ''online jamming'', or ''teleconcerts''.
==History== On June 21, 1982, The first International Summer Solstice Radio Broadcast. Created by Charlie Morrow. Produced by New Wilderness Foundation and WNYC FM. Celebrating the first day of summer (and winter below the equator) with a satellite mix of live events in Sweden, the USA, New Zealand, Canada, Denmark, and Italy. The solstice jam in real time concluded the show.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/22/arts/druids-mark-solstice-euphoniously.html |title='DRUIDS' MARK SOLSTICE EUPHONIOUSLY |last1=Rockwell |first1=John |last2= |first2= |date=22 June 1982 |website= |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |access-date= |quote=}}</ref>
On August 26, 2012, a ghostpianist concert has been realized in Berlin Philharmonie. Italian pianist Roberto Prosseda played Chopin's Grande Polonaise Brillante op. 22 on a Yamaha Clavinova digital piano in the backstage of the hall, sending the midi signal in real time to the robot-pianist Teo Tronico, which acted as a mirrorpianist, mirroring Prosseda's performance on the Steinway grand piano on stage with Berliner Symphoniker conducted by Michelangelo Galeati.
==Issues== Performers and researchers work to overcome the following obstacles:
# '''Audio latency:''' Most musicians who play in a group rely on audio cues to maintain tempo and other communication. The most obvious example is the use of a drummer in pop music to keep time. In a normal rehearsal or performance environment, there is a delay between the time one musician plays and another hears the sound due to the speed of sound in air. This is typically from 3 - 50ms. When audio is transmitted through a digital medium (i.e. the Internet), the delay (or [[Latency (audio)|latency]]) can be much longer. Cell phones have latency of approximately 50ms. Applications such as Skype have approximately 100ms. And, QuickTime and Windows Media server-based streaming systems add 8 or more seconds of latency. When the latency is too high, the audio cues are no longer effective. Researchers<ref name='lester_boley'>{{cite journal | author=Lester, M, & Boley, J. | title=The Effects of Latency on Live Sound Monitoring | journal=Audio Engineering Society | year=2007 }}{{Full|date=April 2014}}<!--volume number, inclusive pages, and the specific page reference for this citation are needed.--></ref> have shown that some musicians can ignore this delay while others find it obtrusive. In general, the higher the audio quality and the more channels transmitted, the higher the latency needs to be to reliably transmit the audio stream. # '''Echo cancellation:''' Since the latency between locations is much higher than the speed of sound, standard techniques to eliminate feedback from monitoring systems, such as [equalization], do not work. However, when the latency between locations is low enough, teleconferencing [[echo cancellation]] techniques can be used. # '''Video latency:''' Musicians also rely on visual cues to maintain synchronization. The most obvious example is the use of a conductor with orchestral music. Due to the size of video data, latency tends to higher for video than audio latency. # '''Audio/video synchronization:''' In order to maintain audio and video synchronization, audio may be delayed more than necessary. Some performers opt to sacrifice AV synchronization for lower audio latency. For example, those involved with [[improvised]], musical telematic performances may require low latency audio cues.
==Technology==
===Open source=== * [[JACK Audio Connection Kit|Netjack]]
===Commercial software=== * [[Skype]] * [[iChat]]
==Performance groups== * [[Concordia Laptop Orchestra|CLOrk at Concordia]]
==See also== * [[Videoconferencing]] * [[Telepresence]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Telematic Performance}} [[Category:Performing arts]]

{{italic title}} {{notability|date=August 2018}} [[File:La_Mort_de_Sophonisbe_-_Mattia_Preti.jpg|thumb|300px]] '''''The Death of Sophonisba''''' or '''''Sophonisba Taking Poison''''' is a 1670s painting by [[Mattia Preti]] of the suicide of [[Sophonisba]]. It is now in the [[Museum of Fine Arts of Lyon]].
==Sources== *http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/joconde_fr?ACTION=CHERCHER&FIELD_98=REPR&VALUE_98=Sophonisbe
{{DEFAULTSORT:Death of Sophonisba}} [[category:1670s paintings]] [[category:Paintings by Mattia Preti]] {{17C-painting-stub}} [[category:Paintings of the Museum of Fine Arts of Lyon]] [[category:Paintings about suicide]] [[category:Angels in art]] [[category:Women in art]] [[category:History paintings]]

{{unreferenced|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox artwork | image_size=250px | image_file=Amante dell'ingegnere.jpg | title=The Engineer's Lover | other_language_1 = Italian | other_title_1 = L'amante dell'ingegnere | artist=Carlo Carrà | year=1921 | medium=[[Oil painting|Oil on canvas]] | height_metric=55 | width_metric=45 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=Venice | museum=[[Peggy Guggenheim Collection]] }} '''''The Engineer's Lover''''' (Italian: '''L'amante dell'ingegnere'') is a painting by [[Italy|Italian]] painter [[Carlo Carrà]]. It was finished during the [[Metaphysical art|metaphysical]] phase of the artist (1921).
It portrays an enigmatic head of a maiden on a brown table, flanked by a green panel with a triangle and a compasses (symbols of rationalism). The black background contributes to underline the timeless atmosphere of the scene.
The painting belongs to [[Gianni Mattioli]]'s collection.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Engineer's Lover, The}} [[Category:1921 paintings]] [[Category:Paintings by Carlo Carrà]]
{{20C-painting-stub}} {{italy-art-stub}}

{{Infobox University | name = Tyler School of Art | image_size = 200px | caption =The Tyler School of Art's main building on the campus of Temple University | latin_name = | motto = | established = 1935
{{small|(as Stella Elkins Tyler School of Fine Arts)}} | type = Art and architecture school | faculty = | president = | students =1,550 | city = [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia]] | state = [[Pennsylvania]] | country = United States | campus = [[Urban area|Urban]] | affiliations = | footnotes = | website = https://tyler.temple.edu | address = | photo = |parent=Temple University|dean=Susan E. Cahan|image=}} The '''Tyler School of Art''' is an art and architecture school based at [[Temple University]], a large, urban, public research university in [[Philadelphia]], Pennsylvania.{{Cite web|url=https://www.temple.edu/academics/schools-and-colleges|title=Schools and Colleges {{!}} Temple University|website=www.temple.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-10-14}} Tyler currently enrolls about 1,350 undergraduate students and about 200 graduate students in a wide variety of academic degree programs, including architecture; art education; art history; art therapy; ceramics; city and regional planning; community arts practices; community development; facilities management; fibers and material studies; glass; graphic and interactive design; historic preservation; horticulture; landscape architecture; metals/jewelry/CAD-CAM; painting; photography; sculpture; and visual studies.{{Cite news|url=https://tyler.temple.edu/academic-programs|title=Academic Programs|work=Tyler School of Art|access-date=2018-10-14|language=en}} Tyler's art programs "have long been considered among the finest in the nation."{{Cite book|title=Temple University: 125 Years of Service to Philadelphia, the Nation, and the World|last=Hilty|first=James|publisher=Temple University Press|year=2010|isbn=1439900191|location=|pages=227}} The school is currently No. 15 in the nation among fine arts schools in U.S. News' Best Graduate Schools rankings, and three of Tyler's individual MFA programs are ranked in the top 10.{{Cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/best-graduate-schools/top-fine-arts-schools/fine-arts-rankings|title=U.S. News Best Fine Arts Programs|last=|first=|date=October 14, 2018|website=U.S. News & World Report|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Founded in 1935 by Stella Elkins Tyler and sculptor [[Boris Blai]] in nearby [[Elkins Park, Pennsylvania|Elkins Park,]] Pennsylvania{{Cite news|url=https://tyler.temple.edu/history-vision|title=Mission, Vision and Values|work=Tyler School of Art|access-date=2018-10-14|language=en}}, Tyler moved to a new, 255,000-square-foot facility at Temple's Main Campus in 2009 with the cornerstone financial support of an allocation of $61.5 million from the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania{{Cite news|url=https://news.temple.edu/news/tyler-move-creates-temple-arts-hot-spot|title=Tyler move creates Temple arts hot spot|date=2009-02-05|work=Temple Now {{!}} news.temple.edu|access-date=2018-10-14}}. In 2012, Tyler's Department of Architecture moved into a new facility connected to the main Tyler building.{{Cite news|url=https://news.temple.edu/news/department-architecture-moves-new-building|title=Architecture moves into dedicated building|date=2012-01-26|work=Temple Now {{!}} news.temple.edu|access-date=2018-10-14}} Temple's departments of Landscape Architecture & Horticulture (based primarily at Temple's suburban Ambler Campus) and Planning & Community Development joined Tyler in 2016, unifying all of the university's built-environment design disciplines in one school for the first time. In 2017, arts administrator, art historian and curator Susan E. Cahan, formerly associate dean and dean for the arts at [[Yale College]] at [[Yale University]], was appointed dean of the Tyler School of Art by Temple President Richard M. Englert.{{Cite news|url=https://news.temple.edu/news/2017-05-08/tyler-school-art-dean-named|title=Susan E. Cahan appointed dean of Tyler School of Art|work=Temple Now {{!}} news.temple.edu|access-date=2018-10-14}} == Academic programs and accreditation== The Tyler School of Art offers a wide range of degree and certificate programs in the areas of art, built-environment design, graphic design, art history and art education. Tyler students also have access to the comprehensive programs and resources of Temple University. Under Susan E. Cahan, Tyler's dean since 2017, Tyler has placed a renewed emphasis on cross-disciplinary studies and collaboration in its academic and co-curricular programs.{{Cite news|url=https://tyler.temple.edu/meet-tyler-dean-susan-cahan|title=Meet Tyler dean Susan Cahan|work=Tyler School of Art|access-date=2018-10-14|language=en}} Tyler's academic degree programs: * Architecture (BSArch, MArch, MSArch**) * Art (BA, available only at [[Temple University, Japan Campus]]) * Art Education (BFA with art education concentration, BSEd, MEd with major in art education) * Art History (BA, MA, MA with fine arts administration track, PhD) * Art Therapy (BA) * Ceramics (BFA*, MFA) * City & Regional Planning (MS) * Community Development (BS) * Facilities Management (BS) * Facilities Planning (MS***) * Fibers & Material Studies (BFA*, MFA) * Foundations (non-degree granting program for freshmen) * Glass (BFA*, MFA) * Graphic & Interactive Design (BFA*, MFA) * Historic Preservation (BS) * Horticulture (BSHort, ASHort) * Landscape Architecture (BSLA, MLArch) * Metals/Jewelry/CAD-CAM (BFA*, MFA) * Painting (BFA*, MFA) * Photography (BFA*, MFA) * Printmaking (BFA*, MFA) * Sculpture (BFA*, MFA) * Visual Studies (BA) * also available as BFA with Entrepreneurial Studies or a BFA with Art Education concentration ** post-professional degree available with optional concentrations in Advanced Technologies and Design, Urban Ecologies and Design, Health and Design *** post-professional degree available with an optional concentration in Health and Design Tyler also offers undergraduate certificate programs in Arts in Community, Creative Entrepreneurship, Environmental Sustainability, Historic Preservation, Horticultural Therapy, Landscape Plants, Native Perennial Garden Design and Sustainable Food Systems; and graduate certificate programs in Arts in Community, Health Facilities Planning, Sustainable Community Planning and Transportation Planning. The Tyler School of Art at Temple University is a non-profit, accredited member of the [[National Association of Schools of Art and Design]] and the [[Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools]]. Tyler's MArch degree program is accredited by the [[National Architectural Accrediting Board]], and the school's BLArch and MLArch programs are accredited by the National Landscape Architecture Board and the Landscape Architecture Accreditation Board. Tyler's MS program in City and Regional Planning is accredited by the Planning Accreditation Board. The BS program in Facilities Management is accredited by the International Facilities Management Association.{{Cite news|url=https://tyler.temple.edu/accreditation|title=Accreditation|work=Tyler School of Art|access-date=2018-10-18|language=en}} == Facilities == Since 2009, when the Tyler School of Art moved into its new home, a 250,000-square-foot building designed by award-winning architect Carlos Jiménez{{Cite web|url=https://carlosjimenezstudio.com/tyler-school-of-art/|title=Tyler School of Art (2005-2009)|website=Carlos Jiménez Studio|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-14}}, Tyler's art students and faculty have had access to expansive, state-of-the-art facilities. Tyler's architecture students and faculty experienced a similar boost in size and quality of facilities when the program moved into a new, 50,000-square-foot Architecture Building in 2012—Temple's first building dedicated solely to architecture. The two structures, which are connected by a glass-enclosed passageway, are located at Temple University's Main Campus in Philadelphia, giving the Tyler community access to the city's museums, galleries and other arts-related resources. Their location adjacent to Presser Hall (part of Temple University's [[Boyer college of music and dance|Boyer College of Music and Dance]]) and Temple Theaters (part of Temple's School of Theater, Film and Media Arts) has created an arts quadrant in the northeast corner of campus. The central courtyard between Tyler's two primary buildings is one of the largest green spaces at Temple University's Main Campus. In 2018, the Nicholas Kripal Natural Dye Garden, a collaboration between students and faculty in Tyler's Fibers & Materials Studies and Landscape Architecture programs, was installed in the courtyard, part of a plan to re-activate the courtyard and make it a space for interdisciplinary collaboration and recreation.{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/TylerSchool/status/1044285110596632577|title=Tyler School of Art on Twitter|work=Twitter|access-date=2018-10-15|language=en}} Notable Tyler facilities include: * The Architecture Building, with four floors of studios and exposed air ducts, plumbing pipes and lights in order for students to observe the building's infrastructure.{{Cite web|url=https://tyler.temple.edu/facilities|title=Explore Our Facilities {{!}} Tyler School of Art|website=tyler.temple.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-10-15}} * A 10,000-square foot ceramics facility—one of the largest in the nation—with four gas kilns, 13 electric kilns, a large glaze room and 3-D modeling and printing facilities. * Fibers and material studies studios equipped with a computer lab for silk screening and digital printing, a Jacquard Loom, multi-harness floor looms and electronic looms.{{Cite web|url=https://tyler.temple.edu/programs/fibers-material-studies|title=Fibers & Material Studies|website=Tyler School of Art|language=en|access-date=2018-10-26}} * A glass facility with a hot shop with two 530-pound day tanks, four benches and four glory holes; and a cold shop with Merker and Czech lathes and four flameworking stations. * Landscape architecture and horticulture facilities at Temple University's large Ambler Campus in suburban Montgomery County, which include a 187-acre Ambler Arboretum and a 5,600 square foot greenhouse.{{Cite web|url=https://ambler.temple.edu/arboretum/gardens|title=Gardens {{!}} Ambler Campus|website=ambler.temple.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-10-15}} * A 5,600-square-foot metals/jewelry/CAD-CAM facility with 56 bench-top torches, three burn-out ovens, a computer lab, a crucible, a centrifuge, two 3-D printers and more. * Painting and drawing rooms, each measuring more than 1,000 square feet with north-facing, floor-to-ceiling windows providing ideal light and views of Philadelphia. * A 9,000-square foot photography facility with two large wet labs, a lighting studio, a critique room, an exhibition gallery, computer studios with large-format printing and more. * A fully equipped, 10,000-square-foot printmaking facility featuring three large rooms for lithography, etching/relief/monoprinting and screen printing. * A 16,000-square-foot sculpture space, including a complete wood shop and metal fabrication shop, two-ton gantry cranes, hoists, an outdoor assembly area and a 1000-square-foot outdoor pad. * Digital services facilities that include a Digital Fabrications Studio where students have access to 3-D printers, 3-D scanning, vinyl cutting, laser cutting and a ten-needle embroidery machine; a Media Output Center with archival-quality printing up to 64 inches wide; and a Visual Resource Center with a wide variety of scanners, projectors, DSLR cameras and more.{{Cite news|url=https://tyler.temple.edu/tyler-digital-services|title=Tyler Digital Services|work=Tyler School of Art|access-date=2018-10-15|language=en}} == Temple Contemporary and public programming == Temple Contemporary is Tyler's exhibitions and public programs unit, which has been led by Robert Blackson, Tyler's director of exhibitions and public programming, since 2011.{{Cite news|url=https://tyler.temple.edu/who-we-are|title=Who We Are|work=Tyler School of Art|access-date=2018-10-17|language=en}} Temple Contemporary's galleries and offices are located in the Tyler building at Temple University's Main Campus, although much of its programming takes place in the surrounding Philadelphia community. Temple Contemporary's mission is "to re-imagine the social function of art through questions of local relevance and international significance.”{{Cite web|url=http://www.templecontemporary.info/|title=Temple Contemporary|website=www.templecontemporary.info|language=en|access-date=2018-10-17}} To achieve that goal, Temple Contemporary relies on a "ground-up" programming model. The issues that Temple Contemporary tackles in its gallery exhibitions and other public programming are not determined by its director, but are prompted by a democratic process spearheaded by an advisory council made up of non-Temple-University-based local residents (ranging from high school students to community leaders), Temple University and Tyler faculty faculty members, Temple University and Tyler students and others.{{Cite news|url=https://www.pewcenterarts.org/post/inside-temple-contemporary-qa-rob-blackson|title=Inside Temple Contemporary: Q&A with Rob Blackson|last=admin|date=2015-08-21|work=The Pew Center for Arts & Heritage|access-date=2018-10-17|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://tyler.temple.edu/meet-tyler-dean-susan-cahan|title=Meet Tyler dean Susan Cahan|work=Tyler School of Art|access-date=2018-10-17|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=https://thephiladelphiacitizen.org/rob-blackson-temple-contemporary-2/|title=Temple Contemporary's Rob Blackson Disrupts the Traditional Art Gallery|website=thephiladelphiacitizen.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-17}} Temple Contemporary's community-focused programming that has earned national attention includes "Funeral for a Home" (2014){{Cite web|url=http://funeralforahome.org/|title=Funeral for a Home|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=October 18, 2018}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2014/05/30/317407504/in-nod-to-history-a-crumbling-philly-row-house-gets-a-funeral|title=In Nod To History, A Crumbling Philly Row House Gets A Funeral|last=|first=|date=|work=NPR's "All Things Considered"|access-date=2018-10-18|language=en}}, an extended commemoration of at-risk urban housing stock and the lives that soon-to-be-demolished homes contain; "reForm" (2014-2015){{Cite web|url=http://reform-project.org/|title=reForm|website=reForm|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-18}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/29/arts/design/art-show-captures-the-wrenching-effects-of-closing-a-school.html|title=Art Show Captures the Wrenching Effects of Closing a School|last=|first=|date=|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-10-18|language=en}}, a response to the closure of public schools and its impact on urban communities and their children by artist and Tyler faculty member [[Pepón Osorio]]; and "Symphony for a Broken Orchestra" (2017-2018){{Cite web|url=http://symphonyforabrokenorchestra.org/|title=Symphony for a Broken Orchestra|website=symphonyforabrokenorchestra.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-18}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/04/arts/music/philadelphia-david-lang-symphony-for-a-broken-orchestra.html|title=A Symphony Breathes Life Into 400 Broken School Instruments|last=|first=|date=|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-10-18|language=en}}, a citywide effort to collect, display, repair and return broken instruments belonging to Philadelphia's public schools, highlighted by the composition of music for the broken instruments by composer David Lang and the music's performance by a diverse orchestra of local residents. All three of the projects above were funded in part by the [[Pew Center for Arts & Heritage]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.pewcenterarts.org/people/rob-blackson|title=Rob Blackson|last=admin|date=2016-11-30|work=The Pew Center for Arts & Heritage|access-date=2018-10-18|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.pewcenterarts.org/grant/symphony-broken-orchestra|title=Symphony for a Broken Orchestra - GRANT|last=admin|date=2016-11-30|work=The Pew Center for Arts & Heritage|access-date=2018-10-18|language=en}}. Tyler also hosts a variety of free public lecture series and visiting artist and architect programs, including: * The Critical Dialogue series, a core component of Tyler's MFA program in Painting, Drawing and Sculpture that has been bringing internationally renowned artists, filmmakers, architects, curators, scholars, and writers to campus to work with Tyler students for more than four decades. Past lecturers include [[Vito Acconci]], [[Philip Guston]], [[Rosalind E. Krauss|Rosalind Krauss]], [[Kerry James Marshall]] and [[Elizabeth Murray (artist)|Elizabeth Murray]]. * The Jack Wolgin Annual Visiting Artist Symposium, an endowed visiting artist program that brings one of the nation's most influential artists and thinkers to campus to work with Tyler students and present a free lecture each year. Past Jack Wolgin Annual Visiting Artists include [[LaToya Ruby Frazier]], [[Rick Lowe]] and [[Judy Pfaff]].{{Cite news|url=https://tyler.temple.edu/rick-lowe-coming-tyler|title=Rick Lowe coming to Tyler|work=Tyler School of Art|access-date=2018-10-25|language=en}} *The Architecture Alumni Lecture, an endowed series established by Tyler Architecture alumni to honor Brigitte Knowles, professor emerita and former associate dean, by bringing the world's leading architects, landscape architects and designers to campus. Past lecturers include [[David Adjaye]], [[Craig Edward Dykers]], [[Walter Hood]] and [[Clive Wilkinson]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.alumni.temple.edu/s/705/alumni/16/interior.aspx?sid=705&gid=1&pgid=8723&cid=14846&ecid=14846|title=TYL Architecture Alumni Lecture in Honor of Brigitte Knowles|website=www.alumni.temple.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-10-26}}{{Cite web|url=https://tyler.temple.edu/blog/brigitte-knowles-honored-sn%C3%B8hetta-lecture-sponsored-architecture-alumni|title=Brigitte Knowles Honored at Snøhetta Lecture Sponsored by Architecture Alumni|website=Tyler School of Art|language=en|access-date=2018-10-26}} * The Laurie Wagman Lecture Series in Glass, an endowed visiting artist program that brings internationally renowned glass artists to Tyler to work with students and present free public lectures. Past lecturers include [[James Carpenter (architect)|James Carpenter]], [[Doreen Garner]], [[Beth Lipman]] and [[Judith Schaechter|Judith Schaecter]]. == Rankings== [[U.S. News and World Report]]'s annual Best Graduate Schools ranking of "Best Fine Arts (MFA) Schools" lists the Tyler School of Art as No. 15 in the nation, tied with four other institutions. Among public art schools, Tyler is tied for No. 5 in the nation for their graduate programs, and Tyler is the only art school in the Philadelphia region to be ranked in the top 30. Several of Tyler's individual MFA programs also earn national top-10 ranks from U.S. News, including glass (ranked No. 2 in Best Graduate Schools), printmaking (no. 7) and painting/drawing (no. 10). == Notable alumni == {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Dennis Adams]], artist *[[Polly Apfelbaum]], artist *[[Timothy App]], painter *[[Bill Beckley]], artist *[[Stanley Bleifeld]], sculptor *[[Moe Brooker]], artist *[[Harriete Estel Berman]], artist *[[Karen Boccalero]], artist, nun *[[Regis Brodie]], artist, [[Skidmore College|Skidmore]] faculty member *[[Donald Camp]], photographer, [[Ursinus College|Ursinus]] faculty member *[[Barbara Chase-Riboud]], artist, novelist, poet *[[Manon Cleary]], painter *[[Cecelia Condit]], artist, [[Wisconsin-Milwaukee]] faculty member *[[Chuck Connelly]], painter *[[Harvey Dinnerstein]], painter, educator *[[Alix Dobkin]], singer-songwriter *[[Trenton Doyle Hancock]], artist *[[Angela Dufresne]], painter, [[RISD]] faculty member *[[Anoka Faruqee]], painter, [[Yale]] faculty member *[[Louise Fishman]], painter *[[Peter Fox (artist)|Peter Fox]], artist *[[Allan Randall Freelon]], artist *[[Nick Fudge]], artist *[[Doreen Garner]], artist *[[Frank Gaylord]], sculptor *[[Deborah Grant (artist)|Deborah Grant]], artist *[[Edgar Heap of Birds]], artist *[[Tim Heidecker]], actor, comedian *[[Jessica Hische]], illustrator, designer *[[Catherine Jansen]], photographer *[[Martha Jackson Jarvis]], artist *[[Irvin Kershner]], film director *[[Simmie Knox]], painter *[[David Levine]], artist, illustrator *[[Stacy Levy]], sculptor *[[E. B. Lewis (illustrator)|E. B. Riley]], artist *[[Paula Scher]], designer *[[Susan Sensemann]], artist *[[James Sheehan (artist)|James Sheehan]], artist *[[Sarai Sherman]], painter *[[Sondra Sherman]], painter, jewelry artist *[[Aaron Shikler]], painter *[[Lisa Sigal]], artist *[[Laurie Simmons]], photographer *[[Nina Sobell]], artist *[[Kara Springer]], artist *[[John Stango]], artist *[[Richard Sylbert]], production designer *[[Linda Threadgill]], artist *[[William Villalongo]], artist *[[Diana Vincent]], jewelry artist *[[Eric Wareheim]], actor, comedian *[[Angela Washko]], artist *[[Hannah Wilke]], sculptor, photographer *[[Lisa Yuskavage]], painter *[[Paul O. Zelinsky]], author, illustrator {{div col end}} == Notable current and past faculty == *[[Adela Akers]], textile and fiber artist *[[Philip Betancourt]], archaeologist and art historian *[https://library.temple.edu/scrc/boris-blai-personal-papers Boris Blai], sculptor *[[Richard Callner]], painter *[[John E. Dowell Jr.]], printmaker *[[Mark Thomas Gibson]], artist *[[:de:Hermann_Gundersheimer|Hermann Gundersheimer]], art historian *[[C.T. Jasper]], artist *[[Stanley Lechtzin]], jewelry and metals artist *[[Roberto Lugo]], ceramic artist *[[Winifred Ann Lutz|Winifred Lutz]], sculptor *[[Keith Anthony Morrison]], artist *[[Dona Nelson]], painter *[[Odili Donald Odita]], painter *[[Pepón Osorio]], artist *[[:de:Gerda_Panofsky-Soergel|Gerda Panofsky-Soergel]], art historian *[[Rudolf Staffel]], ceramic artist == History == Arts patron Stella Elkins Tyler (of the [[William Lukens Elkins|Elkins]]/[[Widener family]]) donated her estate in Elkins Park, Pennsylvania, to Temple University in the early 1930s. With an interest in progressive education and a deep appreciation of her mentor, the sculptor Boris Blai, Tyler offered her estate with the expressed wish that, through Boris Blai, it would become an environment for the advancement of the fine arts, scholarly study in the arts and individual creativity. As founding dean of what was then known as the Stella Elkins Tyler School of Fine Arts, Blai instilled the school with a commitment to progressive education emphasizing the student's mastery of technique within the framework of a liberal arts curriculum. Blai insisted upon individual attention to each student's needs as the basis of successful teaching. During his 25-year tenure as dean, Blai shaped the school into one of the finest visual arts centers in the country, and his founding ideals still remain paramount to Tyler's educational philosophy. In 1960, Charles Le Clair succeeded Blai. Under Le Clair, the Tyler campus was improved with construction of a residence hall and two studio/classroom buildings. In 1966, the school's name was changed to the Tyler School of Art, and Le Clair founded the Tyler Study Abroad program in Rome, Italy. Tyler's programs at [[Temple University Rome]] remain among the most respected fine arts study abroad programs in Europe today. Temple University Rome has expanded to include a full range of liberal arts, architecture, business and law courses with an emphasis on those relating to Rome, Italy and Europe.{{Cite web|url=https://rome.temple.edu/history/|title=50 YEARS OF TEMPLE ROME – Temple University Rome Campus|website=rome.temple.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-15}} Throughout the 1960s and 1970s, Tyler's curriculum continued to grow in response to new definitions of art-making and the role of art in society. New programs and modern facilities in design, ceramics, glass, metals and photography were added. During this time, Tyler established Art History and Art Education departments on Temple's Main Campus in Philadelphia. The pace of change and growth began to accelerate dramatically in the late 1990s. In 1998, Tyler welcomed Temple's Department of Architecture. In 2009, Tyler moved from Elkins Park into a new, 250,000-square-foot building at Temple's Main Campus. Three years later, Architecture moved into a new 50,000-square-foot facility connected to the new Tyler building. Temple's departments of Landscape Architecture & Horticulture and Planning & Community Development became part of Tyler in 2016, for the first time unifying all of the built-environment disciplines at Temple in one academic unit. In 2017, the Tyler School of Art welcomed Susan E. Cahan, who came from Yale University to become first permanent dean of an independent Tyler since the school moved into its new building in 2009. Tyler's leaders: * Boris Blai, dean (1935-1960) * Charles Le Clair, dean (1960-1974) *Donald M. Lantzy, acting dean (1974-1975) *Jack Wasserman, dean (1975-1977) * David Pease, interim dean (1977-1978) and dean (1978-1984) *George Bayliiss, dean (1984-1989) * Rochelle Toner, dean (1989-2002) * Hester Stinnett, acting dean (2002-2005) * Keith Anthony Morrison, dean (2005-2008) * Therese Dolan, interim dean (2008-2009) * Robert Stroker, interim dean and dean of Center for the Arts (2009-2015) * Hester Stinnett, interim dean (2015-2017) * Susan E. Cahan, dean (2017-present) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://tyler.temple.edu}} {{Temple University}}{{coord|39.983162|N|75.153556|W|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Art schools in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Temple University]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Philadelphia]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1935]] [[Category:1935 establishments in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Templetown, Philadelphia]] [[Category:Art galleries in Philadelphia]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1935]]

{{Infobox artist | bgcolour = #6495ED | name = Vaughn Bell | image = Vaughn Bell 2013 Sensing Change.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Vaughn Bell creating Village Green, 2013 | birth_name = | birth_date = 1978 | birth_place = Syracuse, New York | nationality = American | field = Sculpture, Installation, Performance, Video | training = MFA, [[Massachusetts College of Art]] in Boston, MA
BA, [[Brown University]] in Providence, RI | movement = | works = | patrons = | influenced by = | influenced = | awards = | website = {{URL|http://www.vaughnbell.net/}} }} '''Vaughn Bell''' (born 1978, Syracuse, [[New York (state)|New York]]) is an [[environmental art]]ist working with [[sculpture]], [[Installation art|installation]], performance and video, who lives and works in [[Seattle, Washington]]. Vaughn received her MFA from the Studio for Inter-related Media at [[Massachusetts College of Art]] in Boston, MA and her undergraduate degree from [[Brown University]], where her work focused on "Nature and Culture: Human Perspectives on the Natural Environment".{{cite web|last=Bell|first=Vaughn|title=Resume: Vaughn Elizabeth Bell|url=http://www.vaughnbell.net/vbresume.pdf|accessdate=9 January 2014}} == Work == {{external media | width = 225px | align = right | headerimage=[[File:Vaughn Bell Village Green 2013 Sensing Change.jpg|210px]] | video1 = [https://www.sciencehistory.org/village-green Vaughn Bell, “The experience of a piece is actually your viewpoint when you're inside it”], [[Science History Institute]] }} Bell creates interactive projects and immersive environments which affect the ways in which we relate to our environment.{{cite web|title=Village Green|url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/village-green|publisher=[[Science History Institute]]|accessdate=26 March 2018}} She has exhibited her sculpture, installation, performance, video and public projects internationally. Her commissions include installations at the [[Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art]],{{cite web|title=Badlands: New Horizons in Landscape|url=http://www.massmoca.org/event_details.php?id=369|publisher=MASS MoCA (Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art)|date=2008-05-24|accessdate=2014-01-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080616140233/http://www.massmoca.org/event_details.php?id=369|archive-date=2008-06-16|dead-url=yes|df=}} the Edith Russ Site for New Media Art in Oldenburg, Germany,{{cite web|last=Bell|first=Vaughn|title=One Big House|url=http://www.vaughnbell.net/onebighouse/index.html|accessdate=8 January 2014}}{{cite web|title=About Vaughn Bell|url=http://blog.artsusa.org/?author=267%22|publisher=ARTSblog|accessdate=9 January 2014}} the Owens Walter E. Terhune Art Gallery in Ohio,{{cite web|title=Owens Walter E. Terhune Art Gallery Presents "Vaughn Bell: Transported Landscapes" Exhibit, Feb. 18 – March 29|url=https://www2.owens.edu/news-releases/?p=1854|publisher=Owens Community College|date=2011-02-10|accessdate=2014-01-08}} and the [[Schuylkill Center for Environmental Education]]{{cite web|title=Welcome Home|url=http://www.schuylkillcenter.org/art/?ha_exhibit=welcome-home|publisher=Schuylkill Center|accessdate=8 January 2014}} and [[Chemical Heritage Foundation]]{{cite web|last=Thomas-Anderson|first=Monet|title=Sensing Change at the Chemical Heritage Foundation|url=http://campusphilly.org/2013/07/01/sensing-change-at-the-chemical-heritage-foundation/|publisher=Campus Philly|date=2013-07-01|accessdate=8 January 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130804044427/http://campusphilly.org/2013/07/01/sensing-change-at-the-chemical-heritage-foundation/|archive-date=4 August 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} in Philadelphia, PA. Her work has been featured in Artnews, Afterimage, and Arcade Journal, among others. Many of her pieces are "personal biospheres", living spaces into which people can insert themselves at eye-to-ground level to intimately experience the sight, smell, and touch of a growing world. Some are single-person environments while others, like the "biosphere for three" at the Edith Russ House, accommodate multiple people. Vaughn Bell has also explored the boundaries between plants and people by making plants a part of wearable clothing, and treating them like pets.{{cite web|title=Vaughn Bell|url=http://www.greenmuseum.org/artist_index.php?artist_id=166|publisher=greenmuseum.org|date=2010|accessdate=9 January 2014}} Bell has been employed as a “staff artist” by the Seattle Department of Transportation (SDOT), working on arts planning and integrating design enhancements into public projects such as trails, sidewalks, and bridges.{{cite web|last=Bell|first=Vaughn|title=Embedded in Transportation|url=http://blog.artsusa.org/2011/04/12/embedded-in-transportation/|publisher=ARTSblog|date=2011-04-12|accessdate=2014-01-08}} == Grants, commissions and awards == ;2010:4Culture Grant for ALIVE (A Low Impact Vehicle Exhibition) ;2009-2010:Jack Straw Productions New Media Gallery Residency ;2009:4Culture Special Projects Grant recipient for "This Land" book ;2007:4Culture Special Projects Grant recipient for "From Sea to Shining Sea" :4Culture Site Specific Performance Network Grant for "CUV” :Kamiyama Japan International Artist in Residence ;2006:Full Fellowship, Vermont Studio Center :Nancy Graves Foundation Fellow, Millay Colony ;2005:Home Biosphere Commission for the offices of Carmichael Lynch, Minneapolis, MN ;2004:Artist in Research Grant, Berwick Research '''Yeh Dil Maange More!''' is an [[advertising slogan]] coined for [[Pepsi]] at [[J. Walter Thompson|JWT]] by [[Anuja Chauhan]] in 1998.<ref name=ec/> It combines [[Hindustani language|Hindustani]] and [[English language|English]], and literally meaning ''This Heart Desires More'', which later became a popular slogan. The slogan and its derivatives have been used in multiple contexts in [[India]]. The worldwide Pepsi commercial featuring the song, ''[[Ask for More]]'', written by [[Janet Jackson]] was released in November 1998, later released a single in January 1999.<ref>[{{BillboardURLbyName|artist=janet jackson|chart=all}} Billboard - Janet Jackson's Discography]</ref><ref>[http://www.mtv.com/music/artist/jackson_janet/albums.jhtml?albumId=2213775 MTV - Janet Jackson - ''Ask For More'' (Pepsi Single)]</ref>
==History== The slogan has its origins as a commercial slogan for [[Pepsi]] advertisement in 1998,<ref name="midday2009rst">{{Citation | title=His soul sang Yeh Dil Maange More | newspaper=Mid-Day, Delhi | date=2009-07-21 | accessdate = 2009-07-24 | url=http://www.mid-day.com/news/2009/jul/210709-Captain-Vikram-Batra-Martyr-Kargil-War-Hero-Indomitables-Pepsi-Delhi.htm | quote=''... and Pepsi listened. Captain Vikram Batra, all of 24 when he turned martyr, was recommended for Mahavir Chakra, but went on to win the Param Vir Chakra ...''}}</ref> at [[J. Walter Thompson|JWT]] by [[Anuja Chauhan]] who eventually became Vice President and Executive Creative Director at JWT, Delhi, and author of books like, ''[[The Zoya Factor]]'' (2008).<ref name=ec>{{cite news|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/news-by-company/corporate-announcement/Anuja-Chauhan-puts-in-papers-at-JWT/articleshow/6322248.cms|title=Anuja Chauhan puts in papers at JWT|date=Aug 2010|work=Economic Times}}</ref> Thereafter it soon gained mass popularity, and became a battle slogan and rallying cry, first used by Capt. [[Vikram Batra]], an officer of the [[Indian Army]], during the 1999 [[Kargil War]] and widely reported in the media.<ref name="midday2009rst" /><ref name="midday2009qgh">{{Citation | title=Bravehearts say, yeh dil mange more | newspaper=Mid-Day, Delhi | date=2009-03-26 | accessdate = 2009-07-24 | url=http://www.mid-day.com/news/2009/mar/260309-NSG-commandos-serious-injuries-Mumbai-terror-attack-bravehearts.htm | quote=''... 2 NSG commandos seriously injured during Mumbai terror attack can't wait for action again ...''}}</ref> Captain Batra was martyred during the war in July 1999 was posthumously awarded the [[Param Vir Chakra]], India's highest military honour.<ref name="pvc">{{cite web|title=Kargil Update: Indian Army|url=http://armedforces.nic.in/airforce/afkargil/airpvc.htm|work=Param Vir Chakra|publisher=Ministry of Defence, Government of India|accessdate=26 July 2010}}</ref> The slogan continues to be a part of the Indian [[popular culture]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Yeh dil maange more!|url=http://www.mumbaimirror.com/net/mmpaper.aspx?Page=article&sectid=30&contentid=20080401200804010207191839f60c64d|work= Mumbai Mirror}}</ref>
In 2004, it was used as a title for a [[Bollywood]] movie, ''[[Dil Maange More]]'' starring [[Shahid Kapoor]].
==Pepsi advertisement== The slogan was coined as a [[tagline]] for a Pepsi [[television advertisement]] series that first ran in December 1998 and sought to establish Pepsi as a strong brand with Indian youth.<ref name="butcher2003">{{Citation | title=Transnational television, cultural identity and change: When STAR came to India | first=Melissa | last=Butcher | year=2003 | publisher=SAGE | isbn=0-7619-9766-0 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=DNh1qs24HLUC | quote=''... much of the vocabulary highlights a perception of youth today as more ambitious and more individualistic ... Pepsi's 1998 commercial, Yeh Dil Maange More (This Heart Wants More), joins a list of advertisements that play on this theme ...''}}</ref> It was a continuation of Pepsi's advertising campaign in the mid-to-late nineties, which it had initially launched as an [[ambush marketing]] effort against [[Coca-Cola]] during the [[1996 Cricket World Cup]].<ref name="amis2005">{{Citation | title=Global sport sponsorship | author=John Amis, T. Bettina Cornwell | year=2005 | publisher=Berg Publishers | isbn=1-84520-081-0 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=jw-WHdztdDQC | quote=''... Pepsi attempted to hijack Coca-Cola's official sponsorship of the 1996 Cricket World Cup ... the most disliked words among Indian youth were "official", "corruption" and "discipline" ... In an effort to attract youth, Pepsi developed the slogan "Yeh Dil Maange More" ...''}}</ref> The ads featured prominent sports personalities and film stars, such as [[Sachin Tendulkar]], [[Shahrukh Khan]], [[Amitabh Bachchan]], and [[Pawan Kalyan]] and were directed by [[Prahlad Kakkar]], a veteran ad film director.<ref name="finexp2005gtl">{{Citation | title=HC stays overseas release of film ‘Dil Maange More’ | newspaper=Financial Express | date=2005-01-05 | accessdate = 2009-07-24 | url=http://www.financialexpress.com/news/hc-stays-overseas-release-of-film-dil-maange-more/123511/ | quote=''... Pepsi had coined the phrase ‘yeh dil maange more’ for its advertising campaign in December 1998 ... Sachin Tendulkar, Aamir Khan, Amitabh Bachchan ... earlier Coca-Cola, Omni Ltd, the producers of Tamil film Pepsi-Inda Ullam Kekkume More (Translation of Pepsi-yeh dil maange more), and North Delhi Power Corporation (users of phrase yeh dil maange more electricity) were restrained from using the said slogan/title ...''}}</ref> The catchphrase became a runaway success and other business entities sought to appropriate it in their messaging. Pepsi litigated actively to assert an exclusive right to use the slogan.<ref name="finexp2005gtl" />
